If you want to pay overprice for the basics of French cuisine, this is the right place for you. Oh, by the way, don't bother make a reservation, you will still wait to be seated and might not even have a waiter assign to yourself! Welcome to legendary French service!

My wife and I decided to try this place given that it is located in the hotel we were staying in. We thought an early happy hour would be a good choice because that would give us the ability to experience some food and drink without it being too busy during peaks hours. 

We sat at the bar and shortly after were approached by a wonderful and polite bartender (I didn't get her name). We ordered a glass of white wine and a French 75, along with the salmon tartare. The drinks tasted fabulous, and when the salmon arrived, we were both impressed. The presentation and the taste were extraordinary. We later ordered the steak tartare and were also impressed! It was a really fun experience, and having been to France several times, a very authentic one. 

If/when I am ever back in Vegas I will definitely head to this place again. I would love to try more on their menu as I am sure it will taste as great or better.

What's not to like about Bardot? It's reminiscent of any bistro in Paris - right down to the actual menu items. Service was impeccable and you can never go wrong with the classics. 

I had the escargot appetizer. Each piece was like a little pillow of savory flavor.  We had some other shared appetizers at the table but my memory is failing me what they were. 

For my entree I chose the mussels. Delicious, if not a little gritty. A friend had the salmon with lentils and this was amazing. So much flavor from two items typically lacking in any kind of taste. Definitely a stand-out on the menu. 

And oh my god the chocolate macaron. It's definitely for sharing. But do it. Seriously. Save room for it or just take it to go. Vegas creates lots of regrets, and not having this macaron for dessert will be high on that list

Let's start with the good news: fresh hot crunchy loaves of bagged bread brought to the table, and an impressive selection of craft beers and superb wines! The service is also outstanding!!
The selections are wonderful and I highly recommend the beet salad or French onion soup....both of which are quite tasty, although the FO soup could use significantly  less salt.
It turned out to be a harbinger of over salted main dishes, including the Pork Chop and Steak Dinners. So salty, in fact, that I would not return.
Suggestion/Request: Use little to no salt, and put shakers on the tables for those who need more, and more, and more.
Beautiful restaurant and bar, attentive service, classic menu, great wine selection. I definitely recommend this restaurant.

To start off I will say that the food at Bardot was good, however, due to the HORRENDOUS service I can't rate it any higher then one star. We came in with a group of 16 girls for brunch on a Saturday morning. They had split us into two separate tables- which was fine we didn't complain about that and sat down right away happy to be there. It was all downhill from there. We started off by ordering the bottomless rose. Our waiter walked off and came by later to take our food order, and we nicely asked him if our rose was on the way he told us to relax. Quite a rude comment to say to a paying customer, especially when we are asking a question about our meal. He proceeded to make rude comments throughout the meal. He told us to relax upwards of 10 times, commented on someone "drinking too fast", told someone else to "relax with the wine". He made condescending comments each time he came to the table. He wouldn't let us edit our order for a salad to not have beets in it (which seems very strange considering people have allergies). Every time we asked for something he told us to relax. When we asked for ketchup he told us to relax. Perhaps his worst comment of the meal was telling my friend she wasn't eating enough food, I don't think it's his place to comment on someone's eating habits. The service got so bad I had to speak with a manager half way through the meal, and while he listened to my concerns, he didn't do anything about it. He didn't have the waiter apologize, and he didn't even give us the option to leave our own tips. Our bill arrived and the tip was already included, which he most definitely didn't deserve that amount after we complained about our poor service. Unless you want to be judged and spoken down to for your entire meal I do NOT recommend eating here.

Came here for brunch and had the most incredible experience! The food and service was excellent and our server was very helpful and knowledgeable. I ordered the short rib croissant Benedict and it was absolutely wonderful. Also have bottomless rose which is always a bonus. Definitely recommend to anyone looking for a nice brunch in Vegas!

Service is not good, so that's problem 1. Additionally, if you're going to charge $54 for an 8 oz filet, it needs to be cooked properly as ordered. The flavor left something to be desired. I've had better steak at an outback. You can pass on this place.

Had a great drink, burger, and an awesome dessert (Baked Alaska) here with my wife at the bar with great service. Their Sidecar was at 1/2 price (Happy Hour) and was smooth and superb. Paying $21 for a burger might seem extreme but it wasn't here. Their's was ground prime fillet and was perhaps the most juicy burger (and best?) I have ever inhaled. Think of the burger as a half priced steak that happens to be ground. Their Baked Alaska dessert was flamed table side using pineapple cider. The ice cream was smooth and rich, and the banana bread bottom provided a nice contrast to the sweetness of the ice cream. Great stop!

I LOVED it here.

We came here for brunch and it certainly did not disappoint. The only minor complaint would be a bit of a wait even though we had reservations but it was no biggie. 

My husband and I were celebrating our birthdays and we received a cute card signed by the staff. Everything on the menu looked great and we had a hard time deciding what to get. We ended up getting the onion soup, the french toast, and a short rib benedict. 

The service was great, and the food was delicious. My favorite was definitely the french toast. It was huge and we couldn't finish but I probably would order it again if I ever return. The onion soup was also amazing. 

I would love to come back to try more things on the menu and bring friends/family too.

I've heard good things about Michael Mina and really wanted to try one of his restaurants. We happened to stay near ARIA so BARDOT was close by. I convinced my friends to come for weekend brunch after a wedding rehearsal. We had made reservations but had to add some extra people last minute; the hostess was very accommodating and we got our table in 15min.

They started us with complimentary French bread and vveeerrry smooth butter which was yum.  Shortly after, our food came.  Then the meal turned...average.  I had ordered an appie and an entrée - both came at the same time instead of one after the other, which was kind of odd.  So I ended up eating my Fois Gras with the ruby port gelee and country bread alongside my Hunter's Waffle which I was worried would be getting cold while I ate my appie.  Hm... As for the dishes itself, I don't know if I played it too safe with my dish selections as I didn't feel wowed by either dishes.  The Fois Gras was smooth and the ruby port gelee provided a nice jelly texture mixed in, but overall taste was just OK and not memorable.  I've had better, and probably won't get it again if I come back.  The portion was huge though as I needed help finishing this dish!  The Hunter's Waffle was like a duck confit benedict on waffle; it was nice, but I expected better.  Each component tasted good separately but the combination of the parts didn't elevate the dish.  I tried my friend's Beef Bourgignon Croissant Benedict and we both agreed, it was good but also like the Hunter's Waffle, the flavors failed to combine into a memorable dish.

For the price point, we expected more. Also expected more on the service side.  Maybe it was just because I didn't order a drink (?) as I had 1 glass of water the entire meal not refilled.  I hope my friends at the other end of the table who ordered the bottomless Rose had more luck getting refills.

Simple and Sweet

This place is an extremely romantic place to have dinner! As for my case i went here with friends and it was really amazing. The seafood tower (appetizer) we ordered was amazing. The waitresses explained each seafood's origin and my goodness were they fresh!  The crab, shrimp, lobster, and oysters were just spot on! I personally also got the french onion soup and for me it was a tad salty but the taste was really good. The caramelized onions just melted in my mouth and with the sharp swiss cheese its a perfect bite. 

The main entree that i ordered was the steak and frites. Their steak options are limited which i like because id rather that restaurants be amazing at a few things than mediocre at many. The steak was grilled perfectly and seasoned nicely. The sauce that i chose to pair my steak with was a bearnaise sauce which was quite nice. 

The dessert that i got was the apple tarte tartin which was a good way to finish up a heavy meal *.* I also got a coffee to go with the apple tarte which made it even more divine. Their coffee is amazing so make sure to pair with any of their desserts because they are a bit sweet. 

The price I would say is pretty fair considering the ambiance, quantity, quality, and location. Lucky for me i did not have to pay but had i had to my bill would have been about $100. Nevertheless i would come back! It was really tasty and quality is quite amazing. Also thanks to the amazing staff here for being so friendly and helpful to us! 

Cheers!

This is one of the best Las Vegas casino restaurants, hands down. There are so many places where it all just gets mailed in, this is not one of them. It starts with the kitchen team and extends to the front of the house. If you're price cautious you can absolutely navigate the menu to keep it reasonable and if not, then you can live decadently with the handful of more extravagant dishes. 

Stand outs included the escargot (best I ever had), foie gras parfait, the seasonal specials (a salad and a ravioli-type of thing topped with truffle), mac and cheese, the scallops and the wellington. And of course the fresh bread, delicious!

You can't go wrong picking Bardot as one of your vacation restaurant choices or as a place for locals to celebrate on The Strip.

In all fairness I want to start this off by saying that I really wanted my dining experience to be more positive than it turned out to be, but after my experiences with Bardot (even post visit) I'd be doing a disservice if I rated this any higher.

So on a rare instance the wife and I ventured to Vegas to ring in Christmas and due to the strip being cluttered with people we decided to find something "local" as we were staying at Monte Carlo to test our palette with and that lead us to Bardot on a random walk back to the room, but had I known what was in store for us I'd have kept walking.

Earlier in the day I had my heart set on ordering a lobster to sort of spoil myself since it was a holiday and I looked at the 1/2 Maine lobster here which from Yelpers of previous looked to die for. As we ordered, I came to find out they were out of lobster for the night (after the fact) due to their shipment not being up to the manager's (Robert) standard. That believe it or not was a plus for me through this whole ordeal. I do appreciate the fact they want to put out quality dishes bad as I was craving for some lobster. 

What fell horribly flat for me was just about everything from that point on. After hearing of the whole lobster ordeal, as an alternative I just went ahead and ordered the 1/2 dozen wild Mexican shrimp. Call me crazy, but a $22 price tag for only 6 shrimp does seem a bit outlandish to me. To its credit, the shrimp was fresh and tasted pretty good, but in the end I was left desiring more bang for those bucks. I could've found a shrimp cocktail for half the price and possibly double the taste somewhere else, it is Vegas and all right?

My main cause of disapproval was our waiter, Jesus (not good when you remember names). I felt even from the initial point of the meal he was condescending to both myself and especially my wife. All through the meal he made very snarky yet sarcastic comments about various things and we both felt as the meal wrapped up we didn't deserve to even be dining there. We stayed respectful and just focused on each other, but totally inappropriate on all levels!

After the meal we mutually agreed to call back and at the very least make the manager aware of our experience. We weren't looking to be compensated for anything as were just glad it's over, but even a shred of empathy from the manager (Robert) would've given me some shred of hope as I write this. Just his overall approach to our feedback was standoffish and he brushed it off with a very arrogant attitude. Rather than apologize for any of this he ended up simply comping my portion of the meal which I mean was a good gesture, but 100% truth here; all I wanted was an apology for how HIS server spoke to us that night.

Vegas is a city where change is always evident and I do hope Aria makes note of situations like this because as much as Bardot is a reflection of itself, it is in the grand scheme of things a reflection of Aria as well and I actually love it there for gambling purposes and even the rooms, but pardon et moi if the dining experiences have even me saying au revior!

A beautiful meal and experience from start to end. Food is fantastic and done so well. Familiar flavors but elevated and done so delicately you can taste and see the work put into it.  Chef Josh Smith raises the bar.  I look forward to the new additions to the menu every few months. Every time I return it gets better, is that possible?! Favorites: beef Wellington, duck l'orange, foie spread, "best" butter, seasonal deconstructed lobster tail, melon salad, Mille feuille, baked Alaska. Looking forward to returning!

Very authentic and stylelish surroundings meets the eye, adding that extra to the total experience. 
The food is of very High quality and so is the service. Our waiter had the knowledge needed to recommend Wine and food that fitted our desires. 
The Prices are in the higher end, but fair. Only thing I could ask for more, was a bigger appetite

Maybe the best breakfast I've ever had. 
French toast with a side of bacon.  My wife had the beef short rib Benedict.  Ummmmmm.  
Atmosphere: great. 
Food:  A triple plusssssss!
We are Las Vegad locals, have tried most of the places in town. 
This place is at the top!

Elegant yet approachable. We went here for a nice birthday dinner and some of us had never had escargot before. Our waiter was amazing, his explanations of the food were relatable, and his recommendations were on point. The food was delicious and I would highly recommend.

Food: 
Drinks: 
Service: 

Though the overall experience wasn't bad, I will not go back. There wasn't any dish that was great. Everything was just average. Recommend the bone marrow and the pork chop. Say no to the escargot and the halibut.

As always, Michael Mina restaurants provide the perfect setting for a great meal. The seared foie gras served on top of beluga lentils was a nice start to our meal. Perfectly seared, buttery and delicious. We also tried the duck wings a l'orange which were ok, but didn't cause much of an impression on me. The salmon entree was served also with beluga lentils. Nice and crispy on the outside, however mine was slightly overcooked. Nonetheless the flavors were on point. The wine list, including by the glass, was as expected excellent with lots of French options. Dessert was the baba au rhum which was not a traditional cake, it was more like a loaf of bread, with lots of rum and light chantilly cream.

My gf's and I were staying at Aria and this restaurant was luckily downstairs. It's hard to find good French food/restaurant in LA so I was pretty excited to check out Bardot. The inside is very nice, romantic and dim. It looked very Parisian. As you are seated they give you complimentary baguette, which is amazing! You know it's a darn good bread if when you break it you can hear the crackle, but still be soft in the inside. Very fresh and just what a baguette should be. The butter was standard but even better when you added a pinch of sea salt. We all were in the mood for a bunch of appetizers, rather than big meals per se. 

_Bardot Salad ($14) Gem lettuce, Dijon vinaigrette. Simple, yet very tasteful. The lettuce were huge, fresh and crisp. The vinaigrette was a tad sweet, acidic and tart. I love the lingering taste of the Dijon. A bit pricey for a very simple salad with just some greens, but also very good if you want something to start with.
_Foie Gras Parfait ($18) Chilled mousse of la belle foie gras, ruby port gelée grilled country bread. This was an automatic for all of us. I mean can I get a amen or an amen! The 4 thick slices of baguette were crisp, yet soft in the outside. The parfait was silky, and not gamey. The ruby port on top helped to cut out any gamey flavor that may linger and give it a sweetness and tartness flavor that is always the best when eating a parfait. One of my favorite dishes of the night! A bit rich but worth unbuttoning your pants for :)
_Escargots Bardot ($19) Wild burgundy snails wrapped individually in puff pastry, toasted hazelnuts chartreuse-garlic butter. This was pretty tiny and came in 6 servings. I got to eat one, although I wish I could have had more not only because It tasted so good but I felt one wasn't enough to really capture the flavor as they are so tiny. The puff pastry was nicely fried and a very thin layer at that, a little buttery and flaky. The snail flavor was a tad chewy, but overall cooked perfectly. The texture almost seemed more like mushrooms, if you did not know, you would not guess you were eating snails.
_Black Truffle French Fries ($14) When we first got this our waitress made a mistake and brought us regular fries. My friend and I kept thinking and saying not only do I not taste truffle at all, I don't even smell it. Glad to know we switched it off for actual truffle fries. When it came you can already tell by the color and aroma it was truffle. The aioli was great and paired perfect with the fries, it actually brought out the truffle flavor more. I will say, our tables all agreed the fries were so darn oily! As I ate just one fry I can already see all the oil on my fingertips. 
_Burrata Salad. This was a bit bland. The salad was more of about 4 small lettuces, a few snap peas, a few asparagus and 4 tiny slices of peaches. I will say the peaches were the highlight of the dish. Not even the burrata, but the peaches. They were so fresh and sweet. The burrata itself was a bit small and the texture was a bit disappointing. It did not have that silky and elasticity to it. I felt some balsamic or some type dressing would have made this a bit better. 
_Heritage Chicken Roti ($34)  1/2 free-range chicken, mushroom bread pudding, green beans, sauce vin jaune. Good sized half chicken. The chicken was very moist and well cooked. Not dry whatsoever and the seasoning was pretty spot on. The skin was perfectly crisp, although I found it pretty salty. I can see why the chicken was a bit lighter on seasoning, since the skin itself was more on the salty side, it was a good balance. The mushroom bread pudding did not really do it for me. It was heavy, oily and buttery and did not compliment the chicken whatsoever, it was just random and unnecessary. The green beans were good. 
_Chocolate Macaron ($13) French chocolate cookie, valrhona chocolate mousse. Being a bit chocolate fan, when I saw this on yelp, I had to get it. The dessert was the main reason I wanted to try this restaurant. This was a very huge portion, think of those small ones by Lette, but on steroids. As it came out, our waitress drizzled chocolate sauce all over the plate and macaron. At first bite it was divine, as well as the other few, but then it started to get real rich and heavy. I did like the texture of the macaron, it had a nice bite and the ganache was silky, but I would need to eat small bites of this and with some rest in between. I felt maybe the chocolate sauce was not necessary since it was already so rich, but regardless glad I got to try this. 
_Mille Feuille ($13) Caramelized puff pastry, vanilla crème patisserie. I must say this was pretty good but I expected more. The puff pastry was perfectly thin and crisp, which I think is the most important part of mille feuille. The cream was light and not too rich. It was good to have this with the chocolate macaron since one was way sweeter and richer than the other.

Great experience, I would recommend checking Bardot out.

Huge disappointment. Service was slow, which was understandable since it was busy when we got there, but soon we realized half the tables were empty and our server was MIA. We ordered off of the summer prix fixe menu which sounded great. I went straight down the middle, starting with a classic French onion soup. The cheese and bread were the stars here. The soup itself was on the sweet side, under seasoned, and unmemorable. Next up was steak au poivre, and this was the biggest let down. The meat itself was sub par and untrimmed. In the accompanying picture, you can literally see the silver skin and gristle left on the steak. It was tough, over cooked, AND came out lukewarm. What a joke. The mille-feuille was ok, but was made by brutes with heavy hands. This delicate dish translates to thousand leaves was 4 layers of thick puff pasty too hard to cut without a knife layered with thick layers of filling. Flavor was ok, but execution was terrible. 

The winners at Bardot? The French fries and complimentary bread and butter. Everything else was embarrassingly unfortunate, especially considering Michael Mina's name on the door. If it were a more pedestrian establishment, I would have given it 3 stars, but for the $$$$, it doesn't deserve to be in the same category as other fine dining restaurants in Las Vegas. 

My advice, put your $200 on the roulette table. The odd are better than Brasserie Bardot.

I've eaten here twice. First of all the room is gorgeous. Music is a bit odd and doesn't particularly fit the ambiance, but that can easily be over looked once the food arrives. Had the pleasure of trying most of the menu. All of which was amazing. Strongly recommend their steak tartar that is ground to order. It's clear someone has put a lot of love into these classics. You can get lost in their beverage program. 60+ beers, crazy cognac selection, and an amazing bar. Too much to list, staff was amazing, food is good. Definitely a must try!!

Had the most enjoyable brunch with my sisters and grandparents here! 
Thank you Thierry for your outstanding service and honesty! He made our first experience here so amazing and we are so thankful! Food was perfect and met all my dietary needs! 
I recommend this restaurant highly! Can't wait to come back :)

Just amazing food, delicious! 
We had the Halibut, Sea Bass and rack  of Lamb .. with some Escargot and beet salad as starters, just amazing !!! 2 thumbs up to chef Michael Mina

Really bad place, hostess are disrespectful, incompetent. Manager at first didn't want to come and put his face. He finally decide to come after 30 minuts and not even we are sorry. This place is not a good place, rude employees, food is just ok, nothing spectacular! I won't recommend this place to anyone, i will fired the hostess and change them for some that know how to work properly!

Ps: hostess expect to get tips to seat you faster. Stay away from that location

Located on the promenade level of the contemporary Aria resort hotel, this newly reimagined french brasserie has all the flair of a casual street side Parisian bistro sans the French accent, of course. I made reservations for weekend brunch and strolled in at about 12:45pm to a fairly full house bustling with a variety of diners sobering up from the previous evening of debauchery I could imagine. The hostess kindly greeted me at the entrance and escorted me to the back of the restaurant where the dining tables were located. From there, I met the server who was agreeably friendly in a casual way and took my orders in a snap. 
First to arrive was the king crab crepe served with a bechamel sauce. The crepe was rich, flavorful and it was served perfectly thin and not overly bulky like some crepes I've had the displeasure of experiencing in the past. I would have liked to see more lump crab in the crepe but the amount served was sufficient to maintain the integrity of the dish. The addition of the fried egg made for a beautiful marriage of flavors and textures, which had me savoring each wonderful bite. A great start to my brunch and it whet my appetite for the subsequent dishes on my brunch line up. Next up was the lobster benedict on a light and airy puffed pastry. I was mildly disappointed when I spied what appeared to be langoustines and not lobster tail chunks. It's just a matter of preference l but I feel the lump lobster would have been a more impressive accompaniment to this delightful dish but I'm sure cost played a big role in their decision to use langoustine. All in all, it was a tasty dish and I enjoyed the use of the flakey pastry, which was a refreshing departure from the traditional English muffin. The final dish to adorn our table was the duck confit waffle benedict. Served with a citrusy blood orange maltaise, rustic root vegetable hash and perfectly poached egg, this majestic brunch dish was nothing short of stunning. The duck was warm tender and beautifully balanced in flavor. Usually a confit is typically too salty for me but this preparation was just right. The light and fluffy waffle drizzled with the maltaise sauce and the heavenly poached egg added just the right amount of decadent richness to this praiseworthy dish. #eggporn galore! 
Overall, service was agreeable, fairly attentive, and the food was reasonably paced. What Made me a fan was the food! I'd gladly return to enjoy more of that enticing brunch fare when I trek out to SinCity. 
Until then...
Happyeats!

Fantastic food and service. It was a bit loud, to be frank...but I mean, it's Vegas. We were walk-ins, but got a table. They had a stupendously awesome drink list; everything from the brown stuff to the beer list was world-class. 

Have to say I found my new favorite steak tartare dish here; it was so stupid good....can't really describe how much better it is than other places that offer the same dish. The French onion soup was rather good as well, and I really, absolutely loved the Rack of Lamb. All of the food was really good. 

Our wait staff was definitely good to go. The only real complaint I could say is that the wait time on dishes was rather slow...but it's a French restaurant, so am I really complaining?

2 strikes you're out!!!!  Nope not willing to give a third try when it comes to Michael Mina...  As previously reviewed had a bad time at MM in SF.  As for this establishment it pretty much sucked too.  How in the world do these reviewers give 4 or 5 stars????  Maybe they all had colds and their taste buds were malfunctioning... 

First let me start that 5 stars to the waiter who dealt with our table.  He is the only great experience I had with this establishment.  Otherwise let me begin (or end) my experience with this restaurant.  After ordering our meal, it took 1 hour and a half to receive our meal.  Suffice to say there was absolutely no excuses.  The restaurant was 1/2 full!!!!  That in itself is really bad.  

Now let's not forget the "forgetful" appetizers.  The one that most comes to mind is the scallops that is on the tasting menu.  Who in the world serves scallops "sliced"? Who serves scallops not seared (besides a sushi restaurant which this is not). Also they were quite chewy....

But worst of all was my main course.... A rib eye steak.  There are many ways to ruin a good cut of meat.  Over or under cook or lack of seasoning.  In my case it was lack of seasoning.  But wait.... the other shoe is about to drop.  Who in the world serves a prime piece of meat by cutting it in half and shoving it together and put's garnish to try to cover it up?!?!?!?  This was an all time low for me.

Shame on MM for opening restaurants to just put his name on it and collect a paycheck.  Doesn't he realize this affects his reputation in the long run?  

Never ever again.......

Service is impeccable. Christina is a consummate professional. I was beyond impressed. 

I ordered the gnocchi. The most tender perfect gnocchi. In a sauce that I swear was just butter and cream and garlic. With some kind of mushrooms I've never heard of before and asparagus and toasted hazelnuts and tiny chunks of the world's silkiest Brie that just melted straight into the sauce. 

Go to this restaurant.

If you do nothing else stop in for a chicken while your in the neighborhood.. The bites of leek stuffing alone make it worth it and you have not even gotten to the award winning skin and perfectly cook meat.. How are the legs & thighs both cooked perfectly while still attached?? It's a mystery, but why doesn't matter.. What matters is the chicken, go get the chicken.

Omg!!!! There Nutella sticky bun was to die for. I hate driving to the strip for Sunday brunch. Went there last week and it was absolutely delicious. Three of us went and shared a few entrees. Was only of good.

I would definitely try the French toast as well. Well worth the drive to the strip!

Excellent brunch! We aren't one for fighting the buffet lines or stuffing our faces first thing in the morning so this place was perfect. This restaurant has a great modern French vibe and very flavorful food. 

We started out with the "best butter in the world" for an extra $5 and it was worth it. The butter was that classic French butter with a side of rock salt. It wasn't hard and easy to spread on the cut bread that was served with the butter. The tables that did not upgrade the butter had small French baguettes that also looked good but our bread was amazing. Perfect spongy texture on the inside with a crunchy crust on the outside. Definitely worth the upgrade if you like bread and butter. 

I wanted to be a little healthy before overindulging the rest of the day so I tried a side salad to start. Amazing. It had a light citrus vinegarette and very fresh lettuce. The lettuce tasted like butter lettuce but had more color to it. Simple salad but packed with flavor. 

I ordered the steak and eggs for my main. Not the most flavorful but cooked exactly medium rare like I asked for. I didn't see my steak knife and ended up using a butter knife the whole time and had no issues cutting it. Eggs were pretty standard but did look like European eggs because the yolk was more orange. 

As sides we got the thick cut bacon. Super thick cut and it was delicious. No burnt taste to it and so flavorful. We would definitely order this side again. 

Overall, great experience. The staff was very friendly and helpful. Lots of flavor in all the food. Typical French menu with a few twists and extras to cater to Americans. Great decor. We will definitely be going back for brunch.

If a menu has seared foie and a foie gras parfait you can't really go wrong. I also tried the mussels which were delicious. The chocolate macaron was a bit much and definitely is better as a shared dessert. If you are a chocolate lover though, it is decadent and there is a lot of it.

I have only been here for brunch.  They have amazing bread!  I could just eat their bread + bacon and be happy.  Also, ordered the hunter's waffle (good but not great) and the french toast (huge + sweet).  I will be back to try other items!

Really love the decor and atmosphere here - captures the essence of an upscale brasserie. I wish I could go with 3.5 stars, because the atmosphere was lovely and the food was good, but I've definitely had better French cuisine elsewhere.

Food: 
- "World's Best Butter": really average; didn't taste like anything; the free butter tasted better

- Escargots Bardot: each escargot was wrapped in puff pastry - it made the snails have more of a savory taste, vs. a seafood taste; the garlic butter wasn't as noticeable as when snails are prepped more traditionally; a very novel take on a traditional dish

- Halibut: the fish pulled apart really easily and the sauce was awesome, but because halibut is a firmer fish, it felt a little under seasoned

Drinks: Awesome bar with an accommodating bartender.

We have been to Bardot three times since it opened--every 2015 trip to Vegas. The food and service is exceptional. Great wine list and cocktails too. We love the bar design, the vibe and the bustling dining room. My only complaint would be the photographer. We noticed her for the first time when we were dining there for my husband's birthday in September. It has always seemed tacky to me that fine dining restaurants in Vegas send around a photographer charging for pictures. We've always declined being photographed at other places, but since it was a special occasion, we agreed to let her take our photos. When she came back later and told us the price was $25 per picture for both print and digital, we said, "no thanks." She got really snotty about it and said, "I'm sorry you didn't like my pictures." We didn't appreciate her attitude, and I think it's ridiculous that a restaurant would charge that much money and have that customer photo strategy in 2015. We were a table of eight adults in our 30s and 40s. Why would we want 8 x 10 photo prints to carry around when we keep all of our photos on Facebook? They could've charged us $10 per couple for digital and made 80 bucks. Instead, they got nothing and turned us off.

Bloody Mary is a total pass. 
Order oysters and escargot. Stick to omelettes and eggs. I order croque madame only to be completely disappointed by a heavy béchamel sauce soaked untoasted or very lightly toasted piece of white bread with not melted cheese and a runny egg. 
The mgr Roberto took these items off the bill and it's the only reason I give 3 stars and would go back. 

This place is a choice of connivence being that you want shellfish and don't want to leave aria. And yes and it has its stars and busts on the menu. Gotta just eat your way around the land mines.
The service was great, the food was really good and there was a cool atmosphere. And it was a really great value for a nice dinner too.

The Gnocchi here is delicious - the goat cheese is full-flavored and melts in your mouth. The waiter recommended the Chocolate Macaron which was aesthetically appealing but way too sweet.

Service was outstanding. We had a reservation so we were seated quickly. Our waiter was very informative about the menu. The atmosphere - intimate.

Came here for brunch with a few friends and we all enjoyed most of our time here. The king crab crepe with trumpet mushrooms and egg was very rich and flavorful, a can't miss. The Nutella sticky bun was a big portion and delicious as well. We all thought the smoked salmon with brioche was just okay, although the chive mascarpone that came with it was great. We all enjoyed our main courses except one, who ordered her steak medium rare but received it pretty well done (pictured). Service was a tad bit slow as we waited at least ten minutes to put a drink order in. But that didn't deter us from having a good time. Overall, we enjoyed everything, but if I came back, I would want to try their dinner menu.

I wanted to try the brunch that was offered at Bardot and I am so glad that I did.  From the moment we entered the establishment, I was impressed.  The decor was tasteful and classy.  The service was friendly and attentive.  We ordered a few items to share.  I recommend doing this so that you can taste all of the deliciousness!  We selected the Pastry Basket, the French Toast, and the French Omelet.  The portions were absolutely huge and we could not finish our food.  The French Toast was massive!  I think that we could have been satisfied with just that one piece to share.  Yet, I was happy we ordered a few different items, as everything was better than expected.  I cannot wait to go back!

As a pick for dinner from my Brother, we gathered our hungry appetites and walked through the doors of Bardot for culinary satisfaction.

Dishes tried:
- Duck wings
- Foie Gras
- Frese Salad
- Kobe bone marrow
- Onion Soup
- Escargo
- Mac and Cheese
- Beef Wellington
- Sirloin Steak

I have a healthy appetite, but this was a meal that was shared amongst six hungry adults.

The meal starts with some amazing fresh baked bread, I am a simple guy and bread and butter does not get as simple or delish as this.  The baguette is crisp yet fluffy on the inside.

Standout Apps:
- Escargo
- Frese Salad
- Onion Soup

The least favorite of the apps turned out to be the duck wings, they had too much zest for our taste and not enough flavor.

I felt the jam on top of the foie gras was too sweet and did not contrast well with the foie gras itself.  I had to sprinkle in some salt to offset the sweetness.  

My favorite dish was the Beef Wellington because it was cooked and seasoned to absolute precision by the team at Bardot.  The puff pastry was perfectly crisp and the beef to an even higher echelon of medium rare. Be prepared to pay for this work of culinary art as it took a big chunk of the final receipt.

I can't forget to mention the mac and cheese because of the preparation. If i could have I would have paid to go back to see the chef whose duty it is to align each individual piece of macaroni to stand up for this dish.  

I hate to call this out, but the cheesy restaurant photography and option to buy your photo weighed on me while I dined.  I get this is a good added revenue stream for Bardot, but it does cheapen the fine dining experience in my opinion.

Everything else from the hostess, staff, and kitchen prep was outstanding.

A lot of French people were real deal eating here on Christmas morning. What does that tell you? If I go to a Chinese restaurant and see a bunch of old Asians eating there, I know the place is legit. Well, so is BARDOT Brasserie! Plus, you know Las Vegas has become a culinary destination when French people both work and vacation there. I was kinda surprised.

We had perfect Micheladas and split Lobster Benedict with a generous serving of Maine lobster on croissants smothered in what they called a sauce Bernaise, but it had a delicious pinch of nutmeg in it that suited the shellfish. Newburgh? We also had a frisée aux lardons salad. Otherwise the eggs came with no sides. It's a dish best split like we did, like vol au vent with bacon and salad. Exactly what you want for Christmas brunch. Skip the buffets and still get the good stuff.

Oh, and it really is The Best Butter in the World. It came with a warm demi baguette in a paper bag.

Details matter. From every aspect of the decor to the carefully curated menu, Bardot Brasserie has been thoughtfully presented. 

The atmosphere is a joy to be in, reminiscent of many bistros and brasseries in France albeit less worn and perfectly new obviously built with a nice budget! 

This was my second visit, last April my wife and I enjoyed their weekend brunch which on the plus side did offer more variety including wonderful fresh baked croissants and bottomless rosé which both were not available on this visit. 

This time around we were with our children and friends mid week. The restaurant wasn't too busy but the menu offering wasn't as grand. 

The sourdough baguette with butter imported from France is worth the extra spend. One thing i especially enjoy when going to France is the silky rich butter with a much higher fat content than we eat. Treat yourself! 

I had the onion soup gratinée which although good is a 7/10 if you've had other great ones. We live in Montréal which enjoys a French culture and there are better soups to compare this with. I will however say that it is the best in recent memory stateside. The quality of gruyere was nice and salty with a perfect crust on top and just the right amount of chew, the broth lacked some richness and there was way too much bread that soaked up a good amount of the broth. 

My wife had the Maine lobster niçoise and was very pleased. The baby gem lettuce was thoughtfully assembled on the plate with a large plump lobster claw front and center. 

Two of our party enjoyed the French herb omelette. It was incredibly cooked without a blemish or burnt spot to be seen and perfectly rolled. A few of us discussed how they prepared it, with butter in the egg or just at very low heat in a non stick pan. The side salad that accompanied the omelette was crisp and delicious and also thoughtfully assembled with all leaves pointing upward. The hash brown, was a little too dense and dry but could not put a damper on what was otherwise perfection. 

There was a croque madame and steak burger all enjoyed as well but what stood out was believe it or not a side dish that my daughter had! The macaroni mimolette gratinée is not to be missed! In essence haute Mac and cheese, it is presented as what looks like a slice of toast but is in fact macaroni noodles perfectly assembled in soldier position with a delicious cheese crust on top. The square of noodles is beautifully placed on a bed of bechamel sauce, and in addition to the presentation, the taste is divine and incredibly rich. 

While not French, chef Michael Mina has in my view made the French proud and that is not easily attainable lol! 

I highly recommend the food, the decor and the experience for a non rushed beautiful meal but be prepared to pay a heavy price.

Came here for happy hour on Friday.  Restaurant and bar is very nice.  We dressed nicely but not fancy (khaki shorts and polo) and it wasn't a problem, but we were sitting in the bar.  Staff was excellent.  Very friendly, helpful and accommodating.  Food was really good, we ordered from the Happy Hour menu and also got a cheese plate.  Everything was delicious, will definitely be back next time we're in Vegas.

We made dinner reservations for four at Bardot after reading the positive reviews and having preciously visited Stripsteak which is another Michael Mina restaurant. The classy decor, style and overall vibe of the place is definitely one with a throwback feel. Upon entering we were immediately greeted and seated right away.

The waiter quickly took and brought our drinks and informed us of the night's specials. I tried to convince the table to order the Duck wings a L'Oreal but we ended up ordering the bone marrow and charcuterie board. The board was good but nothing too exciting but the bone marrow was simply devine and easily the best I've ever ordered at any steak house.

We ended up ordering the code which was on special and the double pork chop. Our friends both got steaks. They have a good selection of beers on tap and the service and ambience is second to none. We hope to be back soon. This is a great place to treat yourself when in Las Vegas

EXCEPTIONAL from start to finish this restaurant did not disappoint. Went there for weekend brunch, staff was very friendly and the ambiance is just beautiful. Peach Bellini was perfect, warm baguette with butter to start was delicious. We ordered the Nutella sticky bun which was outstanding and not overly sweet. The roasted hazelnuts on top were a tasty crunch. My wife had steak and eggs and I had the lobster scramble. Both dishes were excellent. I was surprised with the quantify and quality of the lobster - no skimping here. Plus the light touch of caviar on top really set this dish apart. Highly recommend this place! We also ate at another French restaurant (not to be named) but in the vicinity across from the bellagio hotel. It was also very good, but the Bardot is in another league.

This is a really nice restaurant in the Aria.  You have to take the escalators upstairs from the casino to find it.  I was a little embarrassed waking in here with my shorts, but they didn't blink.  I guess I'm in Vegas.  Meanwhile, our waiter with the fake french accent and classy snobbish personality greeted us.  He made us aware of the specials, which I'm glad since we ordered two different ones.  The meal was pretty good too.  The price was high which is expected in a classy type joint.  I just think it was memorable.

Reserved a table for 5 at 12:30 on Sunday and was seated within 5 minutes of arrival. We had the La Boulangerie starter, which comes with 4 pastries, (2 croissants, 1 raisin sweet roll and 1 other danish). I had a bite of the raisin danish and croissant, both of which were good. They also brought out two baguette loaves, but I didn't have any, as I didn't want to fill up on any more bread. 

For the main course, I ordered the french toast. My jaw dropped when I saw the size of this dish. I wasn't super hungry, so I knew there was no way I was going to be able to finish. That being said, it was one of the best french toast dishes I've had. The brioche just melted in my mouth with every bite. I barely even needed any of the mascarpone or syrup. Unfortunately, I was only able to eat about half of it. I skipped the almond brittle, as I'm not a fan of brittle in general. Others at my table enjoyed it however.  

I also ordered the double cut bacon and was not a huge fan. I admit, I had no idea on how thick it would be, as it was much thicker than I was expecting. I'll stick to the old fashioned thin and crispy version in the future. 

The service was a bit slow on the water and unlimited champagne refills. Except for the bacon, everyone in my group enjoyed their meals.

Not impressed .. taste was mixed bag and service did not align with the $ pricing.

Great dishes
- Seared Foie Gras
- Bone Marrow En Persillade
- Octopus a la Basquaise

Average dishes
- Escargot Bardots
- Onion Soup Gratinee

Bad dishes
- Charcuterie Board (surprised that it was less than average)
- Heritage Chicken Roti (bland)
- Rack of Lamb Printaniere (worst dish ... bland)

Had a large group for lunch on a Saturday. No wait at around 1pm. The restaurant was gorgeous and everyone enjoyed their food. I ordered the king crab crepe, which was surprisingly filling and really delicious. My husband ordered the smoked salmon croissant benedict which had two per order. The croissants were flaky, filled with nicely flavored spinach, and the perfect ratio of eggs and sauce. Everything came together very well. 

For dessert we had the mille feuille (Napolean). It was quite large, probably best to be shared between three people. It was very very very delicious. I loved the flaky pastry and the light vanilla cream in between the layers. 

Service was amazing. And the bill was very reasonable. Most of our entrees were $19/person.
we had a nice dinner, but we expected better. The waiter was nice and explain to us what are our options and the place is chic but the food was just ok... Domage.

This place is definitely as good as it gets in Vegas!  A group of friends enjoyed a fantastic dinner here last night.  We started with the steak tartare, chickpea fries and the charcuterie plate...wow, what a way to start a meal!  We also enjoyed an amazing French rose to pair beautifully with our menu selections.  For our next course I enjoyed the onion soup...ooh la la - so amazing!  The server highly recommended the herb crusted cod and he didn't lead my wrong as it was fresh, flaky and so flavorful.  We were stuffed, but felt like we had to try some dessert since the rest of the meal was so amazing...well, so glad we did - the chocolate macaron was to die for and the frozen paris brest was so refreshing and downright amazing!  Wow - this is a must visit restaurant in Vegas...I promise you will not be disappointed!

I visited Bardot on a Saturday night for dinner before Cher's farewell show. There was hardly anyone there for dinner. The menu is very french and the ambiance is very french. The food was very good. The portions are large enough to make you feel stuffed when you are done.

This place never disappoints. Always have great service, food is delicious, and the drinks are on point. This is a restaurant that I like to take friends when they're visiting from out of town because I know they'll be impressed. This is a must try!

Growing up in the Restaurant Industry, I fault myself for setting ridiculous expectations only to have the majority of them never met.  My second trip to Bardot Brasserie left me full of humble pie.  We originally had a "not-so-great" experience our first time around, so we are usually very hesitant to dining with an establishment where the service and food were not hitting the usual marks.  However, I decided to give this venue another chance due to the outstanding reputation Michael Mina has as well as the fact that the GM, Roberto Liendo, personally reached out to me.   To have a restaurant succeed in Las Vegas, you need not only quality food, but a quality team upholding the standards that you strive to set and keeping such talent is often hard in a competitive market like Las Vegas.  Our meal started w/ a pleasant (and not ordered) surprise as we were sat.  The Sommelier quickly approached and poured a flute with Rose Champagne.  It wasn't overly sweet or dry champagne so it was perfect to wet our appetite for things to come.  Our Server Nicholas, came over right away with menus and seemed like he wrote them himself because of his innate ability to recall every preparation and ingredient in each dish.  Since Nicholas was so in tune with the menu, I went with my go-to methodology and let him decide what I was going to eat.  There are times where your server will push the "special of the day" if it's about to turn or priced a certain way to aid the bottom line/gouge the customer, however this was not the case.  He started us off with an order of the King Crab Crepe (buckwheat crepe, wild mushrooms and a Normandy beurre blanc) and a Tarte Flambee (flatbread w/ caramelized onions, gruyere, bacon lardons).  If there were only two dishes you can order at your next dining experience here, make these two the ones you choose.  The Crepe was stuffed w/ just the right amount of crab and the sauce was not too creamy or overpowering.  The pairing was spot on.  The Tarte Flambee can have its own review.  Bacon Lardons, nuff said.  We finished w/ an order of the Loup De Mer (European Seabass) and the Heritage Chicken Roti.  Normally, I don't order Chicken at restaurants since I can cook a mean bird, however I wasn't the one making the order.  So challenge accepted.  This chicken dish was out of this world.  It came with a side of mushroom & leek bread pudding that really needs to be added to the regular menu as a side as they would sell out each night because it's that irresistible.  I was informed by Nicholas that the secret of this dish is that the chicken is brined to keep it so moist prior to cooking.  The Loup de Mer was lightly grilled so the skin was a bit crispy but overall another winning dish.  If this meal taught me one thing, it was that you can't always trust first impressions.  I'm glad we gave this venue another look as the meal from start to finish, along w/ the hospitality shown by Roberto Liendo and his team was what most Restaurants should strive to achieve.  Can't wait to go back.

They have a unique menu ranging from bone marrow to mac cheese that stands straight up! The ambiance inside is very cool. 

I wasn't a huge fan of the bone marrow but maybe it's because I just wasn't use to eating out of the bone. The Mac and cheese was tasty and the pork chop was good too but I didn't like the horseradish potato purée so I definitely should have switched that out for another side if I had the option too. 

Everything was pricey, but to be honest, what isn't in Las Vegas.
Great food & ambiance. Everything we ordered was delicious. Starting from black caviar, oysters to steak.

Really nice French intro with great french food . amazing French decor , great service . Also aria is a great casino . hate the fact that they are charging 20$ for parking and the walk to the restaurant is annoying . but restaurant is really nice and I recommend it for sure . great french experience

Overall amazing dinner and service. 

I would definitely recommend the lamb as well as the lobster bisque! 

Will definitely be back on my next trip home o Vegas.

A French-inspired bistro run in collaboration with prolific chef Michael Mina, Bardot is a solid choice for accessible upscale dining inside a Strip resort.

Brunching here is a great way to ease into a weekend day, starting with the bottomless rosé. More, please! And the food options are all quite solid. I didn't partake in the much-enjoyed Nutella sticky bun for fear of an instant heart attack, but I still pushed the envelope with the foie gras tartare and a side of bacon to start. It was quite delightful, with none of the "ducky" taste in the way that, say, seafood can taste "fishy." The short rib bourgignon benedict added more savory tastiness to the whole brunch. 

Service is friendly and professional, and also just the right level of attentive without being overbearing. The venue, which is up a flight of escalators from the ground floor of the Aria, indeed feels like an authentic Parisian bistro with its rustic décor.

I really like this place. We went on a Sunday evening so we were seated right away without reservations. The decor is really nice. Service is great. Everyone from the hostess to the server to the runners were great. We tried the onion soup, gnocchi, and tater tots. All three were delicious. Their fresh baguette is to die for. Prices are consistent with nice Vegas eateries. Plan on $100-150 for two people without alcohol.

The food was fantastic.
The steak tartar was good, not the best I've had but good none the less.
The filet mignon was excellent.
My husband had the pork chops, which they cook medium rare ( pork, not well cook, hmmm?) I guess no reports of any death from patrons there so he tried it anyway.It was good if it wasn't so dang salty.
All in all we really like the variety of the menu. The service was good and overall great place to eat

We had a great experience the first time around, but the second time here was even better. The NY strip steak is very good and was perfectly cooked. The strip is so tender you would think you were cutting into a filet, plus the sauces are delicious.

Last time we skipped dessert, so this time we had the chocolate macaroon and the Paris Brest. Both amazing desserts and quite @ generous serving. Once again, Michael Mina never has disappointed with his offerings. :)

Croque madame. It was made with wonder bread or something that looked and tasted like it! They had such good bread here and this is the bread they used to make it! are you kidding me?!?!?!

The bread otherwise was great...steak was great.....but come on.

My husband and I dined at Bardot Brasserie last night. We asked for a table in the middle of the restaurant and was immediately accommodated. There is an open air kitchen which is nice to see. The sommelier Kelly was very helpful and let us try a few samples of wine. We had clams and oysters which were fantastic. It is hard to find clams on the half shell in Las Vegas! Also the french onion soup and the skate dinner  was delicious.  Our waiter Michael was very attentive, and Roberto the manager came by to make sure everything was to our liking. We will definitely be back!!!

Really enjoyed Bardot for lunch. Love that whipped softened butter that they serve with the crispy baguette. I ordered their escargot, which was very delicious as well. Secondly I ordereed the lobster Benedict. It was well prepared but not my favorite. I just think the lobster flavor overpowered everything in it. Still I would return to try more on the menu. I liked the service and ambiance and the food showed a lot of promise.

ENVIRONMENT
Beautiful modern take on traditional French architecture with some Art Deco influencers. The bar is amazing with gorgeous brass suspended shelves.

APPS
Bone Marrow - Excellent! Marinated very well and just the perfect serving.

Escargot - Tasty little morsels served in a puff pastry. A good gateway for anyone trying escargot for the first time.

French Onion Soup - Very well done. The croutons have a unique flavor that changes up the traditional dish.

ENTREE 
Filet Mignon - Ordered rare and it was cooked perfectly. The piece of meat was exceptional and tender.

Maine Lobster Thermidor - Delicious and creamy dish with hints of dill.  

Seabass - Great quality fish that is lightly seasoned with oil and lemon. This is my go to when I don't wan something heavy and rich. 

SIDES
Green Beans - garnished with almonds. This is my favorite preparation of green beans. It's salty lemon goodness.

Great and affordable French food in Aria

My recent trip to Vegas caused me to eat at 3 different French restaruants: Bardot Brassiere, Mon Ami Gabi, and Bouchon. Bardot Brassiere was by far my favorite one.

We went there for brunch at 11AM, had reservations but the restaurant was about 1/4 empty so not sure if it's necessary. The restaurant is located inside the Aria, and is very tastefully decorated with a nice excerpt from Heminingway on the wall. The hostess quickly sat us down, and the waiter quickly came by, got us water and menus. While waiting to place our order, they brought over French bread and butter. Some of the best French bread I had, although I've had better butter (was still tasty).

I got the goat cheese and mushroom quiche, while my friends got the French Toast. The quiche is literally the best quiche I've ever had (Admittedly, I haven't had many quiches). It was rich, flavorful, and the mushrooms were absolutely scrumptious. The small salad (e.g. pieces of lettuce) that came with it were seasoned simply, but also yummy. The French toast was the largest piece of toast you'll ever see (literally it's the size of your face). It comes with some sort of caramelized nut triangle on top, some whipped butter, and an amazing syrup (I don't even know how to describe it). Every bite was delicious and rich, and given that the French toast was probably at least 1 to 2 lbs, we were unable to finish it. 

I would definitely come back here in the future if I have another chance. The Nutella sticky bun looks amazing, and I'm also a sucker for the Prime Rib French Dip.

Chick pea fries! Delicious. Beautiful dining room, excellent service. French onion soup, shellfish tower, steak frites, and the escargot in puff pastry were all very good, but the chick pea fries were the highlight. Also, the best bread basket in Vegas!
Very good. Foods great. Service is great. Foie gras is amazing. Lobster thermadore. Bone marrow. Duck wings.

Excellent service. Great food. Great place to hang out.

Right off the bat, they serve you bread (baguette) and butter. For some reason, it was the best tasting butter I ever had.

French toast: super massive. Couldn't finish it. Highly addicting. Great texture. Crisp outside, soft middle. Mascarpone highly necessary and really does taste like vanilla bean. Seemed like the syrup had some almond undertones as well.

Croque madame: this wasn't the croque madame that resembled the one I ate in Paris, but still good. It involves a lot of bread and sauce. The salad came in whole leaves, so you have to cut it yourself or eat it like a rabbit would. The salad dressing was delicious.

Side of double cut bacon: I think it came in 4 pieces. You must eat it right away while it's still hot. Once it gets cold, it's harder to cut into. Very smoky and very salty. Good.

Side of hash browns: It's not your normal hashbrowns. They come in rectangles with an added nuance of herbs mixed into the potatoes. Super crispy outside. Soft in the inside. For some reason, this was only thing that I felt like we didn't have to order. It was okay. I eventually asked for ketchup to add some flavor to it.

Coffee was really good.

We came in a group, and we were all looking forward to the Happy Hour Menu.  We were told that they scrapped the Happy Hour Menu except for some drinks.  However, they did honor the menu when we acted disappointed.  But the whole thing was disappointing, anyway.  They scrapped the Skate Wings entirely which I wanted to try.
The wait staff did not have their act together.  A friend and I ordered 3 items (escargots, roasted bone marrow, and duck wings), and we got served only one until we told them two were missing.  They did serve them and we got to eat after everyone else had finished theirs. The bone marrow was okay but the other two looked like they were done in a hurry.
The only saving grace was the Apple Tart Tantin which took a while because they make it from scratch.  Now that was excellent!  But dessert does not a French restaurant make!
No, I will not recommend this restaurant nor will I come back.
Note that the tip percentage is already included in the bill.

Over my maany visits to Las Vegas, this restaura t is where I had tge most fun.  My fiancé and I went for Brunch on Mothers Day.  The service was to die foe, if you go definetly ask for Rositsa!! She was amazing and made sure our every want and need was taken care of.  I had the French toast and my Fiancé had the Hunters Waffle, and it was the best Eggs Bennedict and French Toast we ever had. Make sure you head over here ob your Vegas trip!!!

Our most favorite Las Vegas dining experience yet. From the drinks to the main course, excellent! Each plate was beautiful and delicious. Don't miss the endive salad. Service was perfect. Beautiful ambiance for a special occasion or romantic dinner. We will be back!

There are few times in my life that food has not been for a mere task of satisfying hunger, but actually been an experience and for satisfying all senses and desires! Obviously food can be sinful. 

In this case Bardot was just that! A delectable, sinful experience that tantalizes all senses! We started off with a simple hors d'oeuvres such as the fruit plate which had the most amazing pistachio yogurt with it!not only where the tastes amazing but the display and pleading was exquisite. Nonetheless stopping at one appetizer would not do it. We also had a tasting plate of different pork pates` and presentation with crusty baguettes, thinly sliced cured ham, exquisite French mustard as well as butter that was to die for. EVERYTHING WAS AMAZING! 

I had steak frites which seems safe, but it was nothing less than delectable! The fresh and cut fries were fried and salted to perfection. My mother had the salmon croissant eggs Benedict which was nothing less than a masterpiece for the eyes and a complete the affair to the stomach! Every creamy bite melted in your mouth! My cousin had French onion soup ( superb) and my son had beingnes ! Amazing! 

Simply put the best French cuisine I have had In a while. 

Some people  always rave about food but don't mention atmosphere in the review.. I'm not that gal! 

Atmosphere was comfortable yet elegant. We had my two year old with us and the dinning room staff was so amazing to him and catered To us no differently than the business brunch group that arrived at the same time! Subtle lighting and clean modern French decor was romantic and fun. 

I'd go back hands down!!
I came here for brunch and had the hunter's waffle. It was excellent. The waffle was crispy and delicious. The service staff was friendly and attentive, and the price was reasonable (for aria).

Went there for dinner a few weeks ago after a Cirque du Soleil show on Saturday. The place was packed and our server was really slow (took her 15 min just to bring water...) but that was the only negative comment I can make on this restaurant.
We mainly went there to try the foie gras which was perfect! It comes with fresh toasts and had so much flavor! It was definitely the highlight of our dinner. 
For entrées I got the mussels and my girlfriend got the salmon. Regarding the mussels, the dish was okay, not the best I ever had but it was decent, comes with Baguette to dip in the sauce.
The salmon was delicious, melting in your mouth and the sauce was great. 

Overall good atmosphere, just wish our service was a little better otherwise I would have given 5 stars.

Exceptional experience! Considering this place is brand new and probably still working out the kinks of opening a new restaurant, we had a fantastic experience here for dinner.

A few of the things we ordered included the foie gras parfait (delicious), charcuterie board and cheeses (had excellent selection on both boards). The pork chop was so tender.  My sister ordered the burger and loved it. Was very impressed by the meal as well as the beautiful decor. 

I loved that our waitress really knew the menu and seemed excited about the dishes she recommended. The service was wonderful and we were very well taken care of. Can't wait to go back!

Our server Shannon's service was awesome and professional...we will come back here again every time we go to Vegas just for her service alone. The food is great as well...Shannon's service was icing on the cake

Came here for my birthday not to long ago after dropping hints that this is where I wanted to come.

Located at the Aria you already knew this place was going to be a step above the majority of the restaurants on the strip. Gorgeous modern and nostalgic decor is noticed as soon as you walk onto the marble floor and into this eclectic brasserie. 

 It was a very busy night but we were seated immediately due to the fact that we had reservations. Definitely not a great place for a first date or a romantic evening, as the seats are rather Close together. Great for a night out with friends in town or to celebrate something special.

Started off with the French onion soup and the steak tartar.
Onion soup was phenomenal. Large portion with excellent flavor. Caramelized onions with a generous helping of brioche style bread in a decadent beef broth. The cheese on top was melted to a golden brown. 5/5
Steak tartar.... wow enough said. Topped off with a quail egg and seved with row of crosscut chips. Seasoned beautifully it had a crisp and refreshing taste. 5/5.

Next was the scallops and fillet.
Fillet was very tender and juicy. Standard fillet. Seasoned ok, salt and pepper. 4/5.
Scallops were succulent and cooked perfectly as to not dry out. 5/5

Ended the night with the baked Alaska. Amazing table side flambé presentation but all in all a 3:5. Nothing spectacular. 

Great atmosphere, pretty good service and amazing food make for a great combo here.

The Michael Mina group really knows how to take care of their guests.  We had an awesome time.  The food is so RICH! It was so amazing.  I left so full that I fell asleep in Vegas at 11pm.  I would go back for sure!

Bardot simply impressed my friends and I with their excellent food, wine selection, and impeccable service. I started with the foie gras parfait, followed by rotisserie chicken. These two dishes were prepared to perfection. The foie gras was silky smooth and melts as soon as it touches your tongue. Served along with some toast and jam, the whole dish give hints of saltiness, sweet, and crunch to wet your appetite for your entree. When my rotisserie chicken arrived, it seem like a very simply roasted chicken but one bite into it and it was simply amazing. Accompanied with a sauce and some long bean, the chicken was tender and succulent. The skin crispy after hours of roasting pairs well with the tender chicken to give you such a sensation as you being to swallow it. Though we were stuffed for any desserts, i'm pretty sure that the desserts won't disappoint after such a wonderful appetizers and entree.

Disappointed, as a french woman i expected something i do t know more authentic 
from outside the view of their bar is very fancy. staff is pleasant. Passed the bar is the restaurant, very sober and simple. wood table and chairs, no white table cloth that would bring more class (in my opinion)
i ordered some cocktail while we look at the menu.
we decided for the "assiette de charcuterie" that we shared.
i ordered a steak tartare served with some crunchy chips (i expected something more raffiné my chips were very hard). i picked the small portion of the tartare, it could come as a main entree.
then we ordered the salmon with lentilles and the ribeye cut.
dessert we opted for the apple tarte tatin.
dinner was ok. i was desappointed because i had higher expectations for some reason.

i prefer Bouchon at the venitian/palazzo or Mon Ami Gabi at Paris hotel where you truly experience a french brasserie spirit and class

Came here one night for dinner. The restaurant looks beautiful, nice bar and definitely great for a date night. We got seated in a strange spot, a round table with 4 seats when we are a couple and it was at the walk way so I asked to move for a smaller table and more quiet spot. It took quite a while before the staff came to us to give the menu and took our order but over all she was good. 

We ordered Foie Gras, Bone Marrow, onion soup, salad and mussels. They were so delicious. I could not stop eating. I love this place and the food was so good better than we could ever expected. I would definitely recommend this place. The best French food I had in a long time.
Best French toast ever! It's worth going to Vegas just for that. My Bellini was a little disappointing, but otherwise perfect.

Love it!  Very unique dishes.  I do love ordering a bunch of small plates though!  Our group enjoyed the foie gras parfait, escargot, truffle fries, French onion soup, and the seasonal fruit with frozen yogurt and beignets.  All the starters were very delicious and unique!!  For the main entree, I tried the duck confit with waffles.  It doesn't compare to Bouchon's chicken and waffles though!  But I did thoroughly enjoyed this restaurant.  I would love to come here again and just get all of the starters --- yummy!!!  Still so many that I have tried.. can't wait to come back!

First time at Bardot this past week. Intimate setting, dark and deep, but with light and friendly staff to balance it all. 
Hubby had the lamb and I had the king crab crepe. We shared the mac gratin and truffle fries. Everything was rich and full of flavor. Although the restaurant was quite busy, we did not wait long for our food. They provide you with your own baguette with salted butter, which they continue to replenish throughout the dinner (which I loved!)
Great place and will definitely come back!

Amazing! I went for brunch one day, and it lived up to its price tag. I had the hunter's waffle, which was a decadent construction of various savory things on top of a waffle. My boyfriend had the french toast, which was enormous, as it's a whole block of bread. Also, the baguettes, although a bit crust-heavy in my opinion, were addictive.

The service was very good; our server always checked on us and asked how everything was.

My family and I came for Mother's Day brunch. Like other reviewers have said, it is quite loud. Not so much that it's annoying, but if you're looking for a quiet romantic dinner then it may not be the best place. 

The restaurant itself is pretty cool and classy. Dark wood, high ceilings, lowish lighting. Comfortable booth seats. 

We started off with steak tartare and the pâté. Both were delicious but the tartare especially so. Very flavorful and came with crunchy potato chips. It was a hit. The large order was plenty for the four of us. The pâté was good too, but not a must try. 

Main courses: steak frites, steakburger, chicken French Dip, and oysters. I got the chicken sandwich. It was very tasty. Chicken tasted fresh and soft. Good bread helped and came with some crispy fries.  The steaks were cooked perfectly. Soft meat and decent flavor. I didn't try the steakburger but it looked great. I had a side of a macaroni and cheese dish which was really well made. Oysters looked fairly standard. All told, the meals were very good, but not mind blowing. Simple good meals with not a lot of frills. 

Desserts: apple tart, chocolate macaroon, mille feuille, and lemon meringue tart. The desserts were all excellent, probably the best part of the meal. The apple tart was especially good and had great vanilla ice cream on top. Macaroon was rich, chocolaty, and big. My lemon tart was great, very strong lemon flavor. Definitely worth saving room for dessert here. 

Service was decent, not amazing. Prices were okay. Overall a good place to go for fresh food prepared well and not outrageously priced.

Had an excellent French feast. Food, service and decor are all top notch.  Prices are reasonable for a strip restaurant.  Surprising when Michael Mina's name is attached to a strip restaurant.  Between a Bistro and Fine Dining.  Casual elegance.  Ingredients quality, menu variety and presentation were all excellent.

Ecellent service.  Our reservation requested a booth and although it was just the two of us, they seated us in one that accommodated eight.  The shrimp in the shrimp cocktail were enormous.   Brunch selections come with everything so no need to order a bunch of a la care items.   The Mille feuille was light as air, a perfect end to a lovely meal.

Very disappointed to say the least.  We arrived early to a half full restaurant, and they wanted us to wait about half hour for our reservation time.   No worries - we'll sit at the bar. After 20
Minutes of waiting for a drink, a bar tender finally asked what we wanted. 10 more minutes and our drinks were ready, but we had to drag them out of the bar since our table was ready at that point.  Got to the table where we were promptly greeted. Unfortunately, when the waiter left, it was another 20-30 minutes before he came back. He took our order and when the food came, the options were tiny and the taste was that of an everyday store bought steak. Very disappointing.   We ordered a number of different wines by the glass, one of which was full of sediment. They took it off the bill, but at $34, it was still a disappointment.   We didn't bother trying desert as it would've taken another hour I'm sure. Overall, I would not recommend.  Bad service, bad bartenders, overpriced/under portioned entres.

For a broke college student this place was not ideal for my crew and I. However our server Tish made it so worth it! She was great. So sweet and honest, and energetic! I wish she would've came out with us that night. Kept our bottomless Rosè filled. Homegirl was a real one. The food was good but obviously expensive. I'd only go back for Tish.

Pretty resturant. Friendly service. So so food.

Of course on a 100+ degree day I was craving soup. I tried the french onion soup and it was mediocre. Not much flavor, the cheese was slightly hard and didn't have flavor, and it was not something I would want to try again. The bread was good and the pavlova was very good - tooth hurting sweet chewy and light and refreshing at the same time. 

The service and ambiance was nice at least.

Came in for a birthday. Little disappointed they don't do anything special for birthdays :( also kinda got ignored after a large table came in next to us. Food was okay, had the chicken and lamb. Probably won't try again.
The pork chops and truffle mac and cheese are friggin awesome... and Eric at the bar is the best!  Super good food and a cool bar tender... This place kicks @ss!!

My wife and I came here on a recent trip to Las Vegas along with a friend.  We had appetizers of bone marrow, foie gras parfait and beet salad.  Our friend really wanted the foie gras, but had glutten issues so could not have the bread.  The waiter had suggested the thin potato fries they make for another dish, but he wasn't sure how it would taste.  We ordered it with the chips on the side.  It was actually really delicious with the chips.  The beet salad was extremely good, but the bone marrow was not as flavorful as it could have been.  It was the only disappointment in an otherwise exceptional dinner.  For entrees we had Loup de Mer (sea bass), the salmon and the Parisian Gnocchi.  All three preparations was absolutely wonderful.  We had to try the Giant Chocolate Macaron, and it was as wonderful as it looked.  The service was great, and no one was rushed to finish.  Our waiter was really helpful with letting our friend know which dishes not to choose because of the gluten issue.  A very delightful evening.

Excellent  from  first  bite  to last. The  bread  tastes  like it just  came  out  of  the  oven  at a Paris boulangerie. The   cocktails  are  exquisite. Appetizers, entrees, desserts  - don't  have  the  words  to  convey how  good everything  was. Service  is attentive, but personable - no attitude. I love Michael  Mina's restaurants.

It's been two weeks since we thoroughly enjoyed a French bistro brunch weekend in Las Vegas and the tastes and sights linger strongly in memory.

Before reviewing our Sunday brunch experience at Aria's Bardot, allow a few words about Saturday's brunch at Mon Ami Gabi at the Paris. We had been looking forward to MAG for quite a while and made reservations through Open Table. 

Three quick Mon Ami Gabi observations...
1) a seat at an open air pavilion table, while not directly overlooking the strip is still a most pleasant repast which didn't require a wait.

2) I've never seen a wait staff hustle through tight aisles so effortlessly, while balancing large trays of dishes high above their heads on extended arms and fingertips. Very impressive.

3) we had an issue with over cooked poached eggs. They were immediately replaced by not only freshly and perfectly poached eggs, but with an entirely new plate of corned beef hash (delicious, moist, well seasoned), along with a replacement of their wonderful hash browns and toast. This was true customer service...correct a mistake with an apology and a smile. Well done and much appreciated MAG!

Now, for the second half of our brunch weekend...Bardot Brasserie

While the newly designed space (formerly American Fish, also from Michael Mina) is elegant and very comfortable, there is no outside dining option as it's located on the Promenade level at Aria.

We started with the most unique Bloody Mary's we have tasted. Apparently, the barkeepers use freshly made vegetable juice and the addition of a cucumber strip in the drink adds a delightful taste and somehow lightens the drink. Delicious!

As I was about to break off a piece of the crusty loaf of French bread which was served in a paper bag, our brunch choices arrived. Previous reviews indicated that the brioche french toast was a must have dish. Have you ever been served a meal that required that you just stare at it as if you're trying to believe what you're seeing? Well, we did that. A huge thick (but light) serving which was crisp on the outside but soft and fluffy on the inside. Accompanied by vanilla mascarpone and maple syrup, this, as well as the beautifully presented Swiss chard eggs Benedict made for a totally enjoyable and memorable Sunday morning treat. And there was no way we were not going to finish off that great loaf of French bread and butter.
