The kicker, however was the side of bacon. Sourced from Neuske's, this must have been their triple thick bacon. A five dollar order was plenty for us to share and as good as the date glazed bacon was at MAG the previous day, the Bardot bacon was well, even better.

Excellent service...and coffee rounded out this experience.

Our bill was in the $50 range, but well worth it for such a wonderful brunch and quite frankly culinary memory. 

Our only regret was that with plans already for our remaining two evenings, we didn't get a chance to come back for what I assume would be a great happy hour. Next time for sure.

Our first fine dining experience in Vegas!

Bardot came highly recommended, so we made reservations for Monday dinner. It was our anniversary so we were surprised with a signed card at check-in from Bardot staff wishing us a happy anniversary. (No other out-of-the-way gestures pertaining to our celebration though.)

Once settled, BF started off with a smokey old fashioned. He had the seat facing the bar so he was able to see the bartender making his drink. He was impressed with the way the bartender mixed his drink and with the execution of said drink. It was his favorite iteration of all the old fashioneds he has had so far. Bread service was a fresh, hot baguette with salted butter. It blew all other baguettes we've had before out of the water. Right as we finished the bread, our steak tartare starter arrived. Mix the egg yolk in with the steak tartare and use the spoon to scoop the tartare onto the chips -- the chips are too fragile to directly use as a scoop for the tartare. The slightly salty chips balance the taste of the tartare. If you still have some baguette left over, the steak tartare tastes great with it too!

We had watched the Lego Batman movie a while ago and the lobster thermidor left an impression with us. Why does Lego Batman love it so much? What is it? When we saw it on the menu, we just had to order it. Since it was a bit of a gamble, we played it safe by picking a steak for the second entree. So it turns out the lobster thermidor is super creamy -- so much that halfway through, I had to clear off the excess sauce from the lobster pieces in order to eat it. The thermidor came with an excellent side -- mashed potatoes with peas, mushrooms, etc. The flat iron steak, however, was the star of the meal. I'm trying to remember when I had that good a steak and nothing comparable come to mind. It was lean, tender, and flavorful. The meal up to this point was going to be a 3 stars kind of meal, but the flat iron knocked it up to 4 stars. The meat was delicious, but the side (beef fat fries) could've been better. The side felt too greasy and heavy compared to the lean main dish. It would've been better if they married the flat iron with the side from the thermidor. What a knockout dish that would've been! 

We couldn't leave without dessert and with the recommendation of our server, we ordered the 
kouign amann, which was topped with a scoop of ice cream. We were so full, we struggled to finish it. It was good, though it was not replacing any of our all-time fave desserts off our list.

Service was a mixed bag. Right from the get go, the table was set up, but the bench seats were full of food crumbs from the previous patrons. It was obvious they did not dust off food from bench seats while resetting tables. During our meal, it was hard to find someone to flag down to refill drinks, though they were quick to come by to ask BF if he wanted another old fashioned when he finished that drink. When our server was around, he was pretty good with conversation and recommendations. One thing I thought was weird was that if you charge the meal to your room, you don't get a receipt. We sat for quite a bit before we found our server and asked for a receipt.

Aria's concierge advertised this place as a romantic fine dining environment, but it's pretty loud, like a lounge. The noisiness makes it hard to hear each other, detracting from an otherwise excellent fine dining meal. The old fashioned drink, the bread, and the flat iron steak will remain in our memory for years to come when we think of Bardot.

My favorite restaurant in Las Vegas! 

I live here in LV and sometimes my fiancé isn't in town to go to dinner with me. I don't mind coming here and eating at their bar alone. 

Everything I had on this menu is phenomenal. My favorite dish is the sea bass. By far, delicious! I don't eat meat but my friends have loved the pork chops and steak. Salmon dish isn't my favorite but it's still delicious. 

Restaurant business has high turn over rate. I hope this place stays in Aria !!!!

Had a dinner meeting here with my amazing team from work! The food and service was great! It is on the pricey side of things but the service and quality of food made it worth it. We had the bone marrow which melted off the spoon as well as the ribeye which was delicious. I recommend it for a group setting as well as a intimate date.

Edit: the manager took our concerns seriously and absolutely tried to make it right. I am appreciative of that and want to acknowledge. 

Service was neglectful. Example: my husband did not touch his drink as it wasn't to his liking. Waiter never noticed/inquired. Food was all right - nothing we ordered - onion soup, lobster bisque, double cut ribeye, or mouses frites was a standout, but not bad either. Hoping they keep improving as concept is great.

Amazing food, amazing service.  Nate, the manager, care about the good service and experience.  I ordered the sweet breads, which were moist and tender, turnips were perfectly roasted.  I'm giving them 4 stars because I disagree with the chefs interpretation of escargots, very flavorful but on the dry side.  I learned to eat escargot in Zurich and Paris.

Absolute disappointment!!! We were there this past Saturday a little before 5:00 p.m. The restaurant and bar are beautiful and it was the décor and ambiance that pulled us in. Unfortunately, the service at the bar was terrible. There were two male bartenders, a female bar back, and the bar itself was not busy at all. The bar back was completely attentive and on top of it with water refills. She actually had to remind the bartender twice that I was waiting for my second cocktail, which never came. After 25 minutes of waiting, I demanded our check, which included the cocktail he never brought. I told him he never brought my drink and then he remembered, he left it sitting on the other end of the bar. He asked, "Can I give you a to go cup so I don't have to take it off the bill?" Needless to say, I was furious at this point. He mentioned his bosses interrupted him and he forgot about my drink. Remember, the bar back reminded him twice that I was waiting. I told him to remove the drink from the bill and it took him another 15-20 minutes to get it removed. Dreadful service.

I love Brasserie food and ambiance although I saw not a hint of Bridgette Bardot anywhere - so beautiful.
I had the Duck Wings a l'Orange which were not greasy ( natural fats in Duck were baked off and no frying) with a great sauce.  The Lamb Rack with Pommes Frites was crazy good - not enough but great food.  The deserts my friends had, Pear related cake/cobbler like but fluffy with crazy sauce was huge and yummy - enough for 3 people.  Service was excellent.

Big let down.  My French Onion soup tasted burnt and the escargot was drowned out by the bread that wrapped it.  Wife's lobster bisque had no chunks of lobster like at the Brio, which we use as a comparison since it is very good. Her pork chop was flovarless.  My steak arrived cold but tasted good, excpet the red wine bordelaise was bland but horse radish one was good.  Daughter said her fish tasted good otherwise might have been a lower rating since our waitress was slow. We were falling asleep waiting for the desert menu which didnt really jump at you for choices. What is with them not having coffee on that menu. You would tjink they'd at least have French stlye coffee. Next time we will stick with the Effiel Tower French restaurant or maybe try another French one as we are looking for second French one if Effiel is packed.

Saturday brunch- My husband thought this was the best steak burger and French fries he'd ever had. He also had the Nutella sticky bun, which he really liked. The gluten-free buckwheat beignets were a lot like dry hush puppies with a little table sugar on the outside. Wouldn't order it again.

LOVED this new French Brasserie at Aria! We went there twice during our stay, it was a very good location for us since it was right next to the second floor entrance of Sky Suites. The bar and lounge opens early evening so it was very convenient for us to grab some drinks and bar food. 

During our bar times, we tried a few cocktails, they all tasted so good and strong. They use classic martini glasses, which is very upscale and elegant. Hubby tried French onion soup, it was very delicious and comforting. 

Our dinner was AMAZING, very slow cause it's a French restaurant, but everything came out perfectly, we really enjoyed our Christmas Day dinner! 

Starters:
French bread with butter: fresh and yummy.

Escargots pastry puff: very tender and flavorful escargots, but I never liked pastry puff too much, I always get very nervous if I have to eat carbs. Hubby loved it. 

Entrees:
Filet rare plus with French fries: a beautiful cut of filet cooked to perfection, just the way hubby liked it, housemade sauce was so good, I loved the French fries, the very best I have ever tasted! 

Branzino head and bones off, with onions and fingerling potatoes: FANTASTIC fish, so fresh and tender, flavors were very well balanced, loved it! 

Side of mushrooms: rich flavors, very delicious!

Dessert creme brûlée: it was chilled in stead of warm, very soft and sweet, so yummy. 

Bottle of reserved Perrier was so good, espresso martini was strong and tasty, hubby liked his espresso shots too. 

 It was a great dinner, they had a photographer taking photos of dining people, loved the photos she took, very cute! Definitely one of the best dining experiences we have ever had! 

Just love this restaurant and bar, think we will eat and drink here every time we stay at Aria!
We loved this place. Everything was delicious and tasted perfect. We will be visiting on our next trip to Vegas.

Bardot was one of the best dinning experiences I've ever had. The cocktails before dinner were unique and tasty.  We got to our table and there was a hand written card from the staff.  It was thanking us for celebrating our anniversary with them.  It was signed by the entire wait staff and was a wonderful touch.  Our server, Steve, was amazing both in service and personality.  Truthfully this might be the best service I have ever had.  I will use this as a place marker to judge fine dinning from here on out.

The food was amazing.  We tried alot of new foods so, it was a bit of a culinary adventure.

I would certainly recommend.

First night in town and decided to stop in for happy hour. $7 cocktails and some reduced price munchies. The happy hour side car was great, chose to drink two of them :) 
We were heading out to dinner later so we decided to share an order of poutine. The fries were crispy, creamy curds, and a tasty french onion gravy topped off it all.
The staff was very friendly and made some nice conversation with us. Being an east-coaster myself, it was great to converse with the bartender who was from Ohio. She knew my hometown in PA; we also talked about celebrity sightings and such. Had a few laughs with her and enjoyed our time at Bardot! Will return...

We've had dinner here a few times and each time it's excellent.  Mussels and steak frites are amazing, as is their seared foie gras.  Desserts are also wonderful--I love the macaroon, it's fun and delicious.  Portions are pretty generous, so come hungry.  Ambiance is casual elegant and service is always friendly, helpful and gracious.  It can get crowded during weekends, so reservations are always a good idea.  Definitely will come back!
I like this restaurant. The steak with super fins is very juicy. I definitely recommend them. The service was very quick and attentive.

We set out on a Vegas evening with an idea of having steaks in our minds and better yet in our bellies. I had heard that this place had replaced the Michael Mina American fish restaurant and had seen some photos that had me interested for sure. First off this place is gorgeous on the inside with lovely fresh flowers everywhere and a classy European bistro feel. The other yelpers were speaking truth in that this is a noisy place which can feel exciting at night if you have a loud group of friends but maybe not a good place to catch up with older parents constantly yelling 'what?'. While we looked at the menu we realized there was far more than steaks that looked good to us and we decided that the three of us would do a French style tapas and have a bunch of dishes to share that way we could taste a lot without over stuffing ourselves. I had to ask the waitress to describe the fantastic and interesting way they do their macaroni & cheese because the photos from yelp make it look like a grilled slice of honeycomb that is hard to wrap your brain around but she says they use long noodles and bundle them together. It was my goal to order this dish and yet we were too full to.  We really enjoyed the mussels, the oysters, the bone marrow the onion soup with the deluxe options of oxtail and truffle (we decided not to get the egg). We were having trouble navigating the wine list and so our server sent over sommelier who was a very knowledgeable young woman with wine stained mouth I say this NOT to be disparaging but to include the tidbit that she really is doing the work of drinking and talking about wine and she's doing it well. She was cool! She suggested a very nice cinsaut that went quite well with everything and was at a perfect temp just a bit chilly. We tasted several desert wines before deciding on a Michael Mina wine that was Riesling and Chardonnay desert mix. It was all fantastic! Will most assuredly be back soon and often!

We have been here several times over the past couple of years and used to always look forward to it. This time was the last since there are so many other great places to go and the last couple times the experience has been lacking. Today no coffee refills. No water refills. Took an exceptionally long time for a basic breakfast. No more NY steak and eggs - filet only. Great if you love filet, but I don't so didn't get it and that was a let down. The thick cut bacon just isn't very good. The American in Paris breakfast is "okay," but that's really all it is. I've had the French toast before and that is admittedly epic, but it's way too much for one person. Hunter's Waffle is again, just okay. Over all service is lacking the last couple of times and today the food was also sort of sub par. Bouchon at the Venetian is compatible and far superior so next time we will remember that.

We had high hopes based on the reviews but we must have hit them on an off night. The service was extremely slow. Took a solid 10 minutes to be acknowledged and take our drink order.  The atmosphere was bright and loud. Something off with the vibe. The food and drinks were very good but not amazing. Overall the experience was ok and we don't feel the need to go back. 

Odd vibe!

We had Steve as our server, and he was superb. 
Knowledgeable, courteous, and on point.

The food was spectacular.
The drinks were delicious.

Couldn't have had a better experience.

Firstly I really like the style of this bistro. It's French retro yet stylish, not pretentious like some of the restaurants in Vegas. I came here for both dinner and brunch. Here are my verdicts:
- French onion soup: love the top crust. It's beautifully golden, and when u open it with your fork, u feel the cheese underneath.
- prime rib eye: it's good but not the best I had. Perhaps I like it with slightly more fat.
- hunter's waffle: interesting twist from classic egg Benedict. They put duck confit in between a waffle and the runny egg. I wish the chef would consider to put some fresh green like lettuce or arugula with this dish to "freshen" up the taste of the whole dish.
- escargots: 4 pcs. Thought it would come in 6 pcs as I saw it from other Yelpers' photos. Regardless that, the whole dish is good. 

Will come back and try their famous French Toast!!

The muddled mojitos were strong and above average. The French Onion soup had plenty gooey Gruyere. A bit thick, but very hearty (and filling). The duck wing appetizer was okay. The meat was great. The skin, however, should have been crispier.
For entrees, we ordered the Lobster Thermidor and Cote de Beouf. Though the lobster tasted very good, $46 pp for 6 chunks of meat is nutty. Our server seemed perplexed when we asked what the difference was between Cote de Beouf and Ribeye. For all of you anglophones, the first is French for the second one. Anyway, it was excellent. The three accompanying sauces were amazing. The French fries were pretty darn good too.
Yelpers rave about the macaroni gratinee. It tasted fine though the reason we thought it was fine is because we both liked Kraft Dinner and this was a baked version of that very boxed dish. One would expect to pay a lot for the sides, but $15 for this is crazy.
All in all we enjoyed our dinner, but would not pay anywhere close to the $300+ tab if it weren't comped.
Exquisite French cuisine in an intimate setting. Some of the best food I've ever had, as well as great cocktails!

This place is amazing! Came here for dinner and everything was out of this world tasty! Duck al'orange, King crab crepe, and chocolate macaroon dessert were all the best. Definitely try this French brasserie. Staff was incredibly friendly and not pretentious.

There were no signs on how to get there since the place is newly opened. Some of the casino employees didn't even know what we were talking about. You have to go up the escalators to the 2nd floor of the Aria and head in the direction of the buffet. The restaurant is before the buffet on the right, next to Jean Georges Steakhouse. They have a few tables outside of the restaurant but since it's inside the Aria, that's the closest to outdoor seating that you're going to get. The dress is business casual. Love the liquor rack over the bar. Simply gorgeous! BTW, HH is daily from 5-7PM in the bar area only. Spacious with very simple but classic decor and very dim lighting. The fancy bathrooms are in the back corner, close to the kitchen on the side of the entrance. 

BF was very skeptical about coming here because he is not a Michael Mina fan (he's been to a few of his other restaurants and wasn't impressed). One of my foodie besties went for Valentine's Day and loved it so I was able to convince him to go here with the group. Initially I had wanted to just come here for HH but we all had evening shows to attend so we had a late dinner reservation.

Our Order on 2/28/2015
Foie Gras Parfait: ($15) Ruby Port Gelee, Grilled Country Bread
Duck a l'orange: ($13) Wood-grilled Wings, Blood Orange, Sauce Maltaise
Onion Soup Grainee: ($14) Add Perigord Truffle, Braised Oxtail & Soft Poached Egg ($25)
8oz Filet Mignon: ($54) Topped with Bearnaise / Au Poivre / Foie Gras Butter and server w/ Beef Fat Fries
Le Steakburger: ($19) Prime Rib Patty,, Comte Cheese, Garlic Aioli, Watercress, Bordelaise Onions & Hand-cut Fries
Parisian Gnocchi: ($23) Wild Mushrooms, Goat Cheese, Roasted Garlic
Croque Madame: ($18) Pain de Mie, Paris Ham, Gruyere Fondue, Oranic Egg
Sauteed Skate Wing: ($29) Wood-Roasted Cauliflower Puree, Caper-brown Butter, Lemon
Carlsbad Mussels Marinieres: ($26) Garlic Butter Dolin Vermouth, Warm Baguette
Oak-Fired Duroc Pork Chop: ($36) bacon Lardons, Baby Carrots, Potato Puree, Grain Mustard
Potato Puree
Red - Glass: ($16) Bouchard Bourgogne Rouge, Burgundy, France 2013. fleshy strawberry and black cherry notes overturned black soil and baking spices
Pinot Noir - Bottle: ($133) Domaine Faively 2009. Nuits-St. Georges

Full Menu: https://butterfly1465.wordpress.com/2015/03/15/bardot-brasserie/

For appetizers I had the Foie Gras Parfait. While it was good, I would've liked more of the Gelee to go with it to balance it out more. There wasn't enough bread to eat with the foie gras so I used the complimentary bread which was fine. We ordered an order of the Duck a l'orange for the table that everyone devoured because they all really enjoyed it. Our friends who ordered the Onion Soup thought that it was amazing (it looked and smelled really good too!).

I had the Sauteed Skate which I would say it was more fried. I had wanted something fairly light since I had all the foie gras earlier in the meal and was a bit disappointed in the skate. It still tasted pretty good (just a bit on the dry side). Loved the pureed cauliflower. Tried some of the BFs Filet Mignon w/ Foie Gras Butter. He wasn't going to have any sauce but I wanted to try the butter so he asked for it on the side. It was ok but the filet mignon tasted better on its own (which is how it should be). Tried a bite of my friend's gnocchi and thought it was very tender and pretty good. Not the best I've had like in an authentic Italian restaurant though.

Absolutely amazing service! Even though we had a late dinner reservation that was close to their closing time, we never once felt rushed. Our chairs were pulled out for us and when someone left the table, our napkins were still folded when we came back. Plates and drinks constantly refilled. The wine list is long so the waiter had the sommelier come by to assist in picking a bottle. The sommelier tried to sell the table a $2k bottle, even though we wanted a mid-range bottle so that wasn't to helpful initially. Ended up with a really good bottle though (I'm not a wine drinker and thought it was easy to drink).

Apparently this dinner (and one later in the weekend) got me nominated in picking all the Vegas meals in the future. Would definitely come back. Hopefully for HH next time. Want to try the marrow & escargot!

We enjoyed the les Fromages for our first course and the chicken and steak for our main course. Everything was delish, but the coupe glacee for desert and service really made it a special experience. For a pricey French bistro it is worth a special occasion.

From the service to the food, this place is outstanding! The restaurant is absolutely beautiful and has such a cool vibe! I came here with my boyfriend for the first time and I loved it! Our server Christina was extremely helpful and attentive! The manager Stephen stopped by to check on us and was very nice. The sommelier Andrew, and Chef Jd were so welcoming and sweet. I would recommend this place to anyone and everyone! I'll be back! #foisgras #duckwings #seabass

We went to Bardot Brasserie for Sunday brunch and the food and drinks were excellent. They offer many different types of eggs benedict on a croissant. I had lobster benedict and it was delicious! As everything in Las Vegas it was crowded and loud, but service was good and the food is worth a trip back.

I couldn't be happier with my experience at Bardot.  I was here with a group of 10 people for my bachelor party dinner last Friday.  The food was excellent, the prices were reasonable (for Vegas), and the service was top notch.  

Between the everyone in the group, I think we ordered just about all of the appetizers and about half the entrees. I loved everything I tried and I didn't hear a single complaint from anyone.  The onion soup is the top 2 or 3 I've ever had, as was the beef tartare. My ribeye steak was cooked perfectly and incredibly flavorful. I was able to sample their mac and cheese, which had a look that I've never seen before, and it was excellent. 

I was pleased with how great the service for our group was considering how many people we had.  I think a place deserves to be recognized when they can effortlessly handle a large group.

My only complaint is minor -- I wish they'd add a hard cider or two to their beer menu. I don't like most beers and I don't like wine, so I ended up having to stick to Diet Coke because they didn't have any ciders.  That being said, it won't keep me from coming back!

I'm a Las Vegas local and a high roller in the MGM family, Bardot did not live up to my expectations at all.  It's loud and obnoxious,  and the prices are nowhere in line with the quality.   I ordered the most expensive steak on the menu, and honestly, I  may have enjoyed an Applebee's steak just as much.   From someone who spends tens of thousands of dollars each year at MGM properties, Bardot,  you're getting a thumbs down from me.  Michael Mina, you're name may draw tourists but let's keep it real and live up to the standard you're trying to portray.
We got their signature French toast and Maine lobster Eggs Benedict and they were both amazing!!

So French and so cute. I loved the Nutella sticky buns and the service was absolutely exceptional. Steak and eggs was great, lobster Benedict was great, French toast was a sight to see and was like a bread pudding--so good!  Would pass on the charcuterie (salami was oily and not fresh...) everything else was great

Bardot is one of the best dining experiences I've had in Vegas, and I'm local. From the beginning to end they leave nothing behind to make the experience wonderful. Beautiful pairings on every dish from the Sommolier, very knowledgeable servers, and incredible executive chef Josh Smith. If you're looking to indulge in incredible French food, hands down the best in Las Vegas. Not to mention stunning bar with very talented bartenders! Can't wait to come back!

We've all seen the reviews saying service sucks, or is slow, or "fill in your adjective here." Let me say to those morons this is not In n Out burger where you can order your foie gras 'animal style.'  This is a for real, down to earth, as God is my witness, 5 Star Restaurant. 
We had dinner there on a Thursday night. The Executive Chef was cooking. How can you be sure the Executive Chef is there? Ask. Simple enough. 
We told our server, John Paul, we were in no hurry, and he got it. The first thing he asked was would we like a cocktail THEN he gave us menus. Nice. He got it. No hurry. 
If you, dear reader, are in more of a hurry, tell your server. These guys and gals are pros. They get it IF you tell them. Most people willing to drop a couple hundred on dinner would rather savior the moment. Better yet, if you're in a rush, go to the crappy buffet and complain about that. 
The two of us took 3 hours and spent almost $300. We're not rich, but enjoy a good meal. Yes, that included several drinks and dessert with no comps.  Ask yourself how many times you've walked out of a mediocre restaurant after spending a hundred or more completely disappointed? THIS is worth it. 
What we ate  
Charcuterie Board. A huge app good for three or more. We pigged out with the two of us. In house salami, Pate' and an amazing rillette. It came with grilled French bread, cornichon pickles and a house made Dijon. Fabulous. 
After that we moved onto a wonderful red wine suggested by our somalier. Again. We asked. I told her I didn't want to spend $50 on a glass of wine. She suggested this gem at 12 bucks a glass. A bargain to any wine drinker. (Sorry, I don't  recall what it was)
After we ate that our server return for what we wanted to order next. Get it? Take your time. They're cool with that. 
We had the frisée aux lardon. Bacon, lettuce, and a delicious vinegrette. Light, tasty, wonderful. 
Main course was bouillabaisse for me and a French sea bass for me better half. The fennel on hers was out of this world. My soup was extraordinary worthy of any reward. 
Our server talked us into trying the chocolate macaroon for dessert. Again, superb. 
Ya, this is too wordy, and any editor would chop it up, but I'm hoping you got the point. 
To summerize, just slow down, and enjoy an amazing meal.

One of my faves if I'm feeling gluttonous but not wanting the buffet type setting.  Setup on the second level inside Aria. Some delicious traditional French dishes alongside some fun interesting take on the classics. Start by sharing the prime steak tartare and frisée aux lardons. I'm a big fan of simple dishes that are seasoned and executed well. Both of these dishes are just that. Their variations on Benedicts are deliciously fun but my favorite dish is the hunter's waffle -- a sort of duck à l'orange for breakfast. Sitting atop a waffle is glazed duck confit and perfectly poached eggs that are smothered with sauce maltaise. It's sweet and savory and makes me smile. And don't forget the everlasting rosé. Service is absolutely always on point whether it's at the bar or at a table. Support staff is always helpful. Managers actively on the floor visiting with guests. It is pricey but absolutely worth every penny. Awesome awesome food, service and environment.

On the way to Zion National Park for our 10th anniversary, my husband and I thought it'd be fun to stay a night at the Aria just to break up the drive from Peoria where we live. We always stay at the Aria, and I've seen so many photos and reviews that I was inspired to try this place for dinner. I'll admit, it was an odd night for a celebration, a Wednesday night at around just after 9pm, when it's close to closing I'm assuming. The restaurant was fairly open, except for a few people grabbing drinks at the bar, and maybe two other couples and one small group. There was no hostess originally at the entrance, so we awkwardly looked around. The friendly bartender assured us someone would soon be with us, and eventually after maybe 10 minutes, we were rescued and finally guided to a table.

Our waitress was super nice. She grabbed my cocktail order, Le Peche Mode. Cute name, so the cocktail just had to be good... It had Hennessy, peach cream, lemon, ginger and mint. I'm not the biggest fan of mint, but luckily it was subtle. I enjoyed it much more than the Lime in Da Abricot, which also had cognac, apricot purée, and mint. While waiting for my cocktail to make its presence, we were given a French bread baguette in a paper bag lightly toasted and served with non melted butter. It wasn't pre sliced so we made a hell of a mess breaking it apart and sharing it. Our bad... 

The Escargots Bardot consisted of wild burgundy snails wrapped in puff pastries, and they were toasted with hazelnuts sprinkled on top and delicately bathed in chartreuse-garlic butter. The pastry was very light and perfect. We really loved this appetizer. 

The Steak Tartare had freshly ground prime filet with egg yolk served with gaufrette potato chips. This was my husband's choice, because he is a sucker for most tartares, and this one did not disappoint. The salty chips fit well with the raw filet meat. 

Since I'm a huge fan of Branzino type fish, it was a no brained for me to try the Loup de Mer Au Fenouil. It had roasted Mediterranean Sea bass, caramel iced lemon, fennel, and fingerling potatoes. It looked exactly like the photo in our hotel room advertisement for Bardot. It was also perfectly done not only in aesthetics but in taste. 

My husband ordered the double cut pork chop. It was oak smoked pork with bacon lardons, root veggies, horseradish potato purée and grain mustard bearer bland. Funny enough, this was also featured on the advertisement for Bardot in our hotel room, but I swear, we ordered these 2 entrees without even seeing the advertisement. I just recognized the 2 entrees' photo when we returned to the room! 

The food is absolutely close to phenomenal especially as far as how the escargot and the Loup de Mer. Our waitress was really good and friendly especially for working late on a Wednesday night, a slower night. I think what got to me was the long waits we encountered. We waited a while to sit down and there seemed like too much time between dishes. If it had been a weekend, then I'd totally understand, but it really didn't seem like that were that many people there. There was a photographer there too with an assistant, nabbing memorable photos of the night. It was just slightly on the pushy side with posing our photos for us, and then they returned at the end of dinner to present us with prints of our photos. It was around $100 or so to get the prints and that's only a select few of the prints. She was right... it was our 10th anniversary so we were suckered into getting some.. It was still awkward though. 

If we return, it'd just be to grab a cocktail and maybe some of the escargot pastries again.
The chickpea fries were awesome! The rest of the food was good...but definitely not worth the price.

What nice, elegant restaurant in the middle of all of Las Vegas' steak houses. The waiter was friendly and helpful. We had the cheese plate and sweetbreads to start. Both were excellent. We ordered 2 smoked pork chops which were very, very smoked. It was a bit salty, but still very good. We were a bit rushed to get to a concert so I'd like to go back and try dessert. Overall Michael Mina did it again!

I have extremely low expectations for restaurants on the strip.  I feel as though they can get away with more and have less to prove being "on the strip." 

However this was not the case with Bardot.  I was invited last minute to go to brunch with a few old friends, and although I was hesitant, I was SO happy I went! 

Bardot is located in the Aria, which is already a beautiful (non-smoking, so yay) and pleasant place.  Self-parking *which was not painful* and valet is available for guests and it's a short walk through the casino and up to the second floor for Bardot. 

The ambiance was lovely, although the music didn't go with the vibe of the restaurant.  The menu was pretty, laid out nicely and offered many different selections. We started with the boulange basket, with assorted sweet breads -- made me miss Paris. 

For brunch, my friend and I decided to split both the salmon croissant benedicts and the french toast.  Both were AMAZING -- the french toast was a large puffed (looked like honey toast) piece of toast and sweet, but not too rich.  The almond syrup it came with was over the top.....I thought the toast was perfect on it's own, thank goodness it was on the side. 

The salmon croissant benedict was absolutely mouth-watering. The salmon was cooked perfectly and each bite melted in your mouth.  I was sad when I came down to my last bite.  

Staff was extremely friendly and attentive, my glass of water was never empty, so that deserves a  huge thumbs up. 

Only downfall was no outside seating, but that's understandable. I will definitely go again.

Went here with my girlfriends recently.  It is a beautiful restaurant!

The highs?  Great ambiance, beautiful bar and clean bathroom.  Most of our food was goodish, decently prepared.

The lows ?  We were seated at an awful table near the place the waiters enter their orders to the kitchen and replenish silverware.  The waitstaff was constantly running back there and it was distracting and unpleasant.  Our server forgot to place our order to the kitchen for the charcuterie board we ordered.  One drink was not delivered.  When we finally received the charcuterie board it was disappointing and not as balanced as we would have hoped.  Also someone ordered something like a pate parfait and it was very odd tasting.

Overall, while a beautiful space, we would not recommend or return to Bardot Brasserie.  Giada's was pretty good though!

Excellent service. I've been here for dinner and also Sunday brunch (which comes with bottomless rose). 

Salmon tartine (4/5): I didn't like the cream cheese at the bottom. too heavy

Chocolate macaron (3.5/5): The chocolate sauce is over the top. This dessert can feed 2-3 people. 

French onion soup (4/5): Very flavorful.

Croque Madame (4.5/5): The croque madame comes with a creamy white sauce on the top which I didn't care for. Otherwise, it was delicious!

The wife and I strolled in on Sun around 1:45pm. There was no one at the front desk, but there were 2 bartenders and many servers walking around with a good handful of seated customers. We stood there for a few minutes before waking over to the bar to ask if someone could seat us and he responded we closed at 1:30pm! Well that would be helpful to know rather than just letting 2 patrons stand there like idiots and just ignoring us.. Good job..! Had high hopes of checking them out, but no longer interested.

On a cable show called Munchies, Chef Josh Smith of Bardot Brasserie at the Aria gathered some friends, most of them chefs, and went out on the town to a few of his favorite Las Vegas restaurants. Along the way, I learned a bunch about Josh's philosophies for food, preparation and creativity. He brought a good deal of his personality to Bardot Brasserie, and I wanted to experience French cuisine at it's finest. A true french bistro is a tough find when in Las Vegas recently, I had the opportunity to escape from my obligations to have dinner at the restaurant. I asked to speak with Josh and a short time later he came over to my table and I invited him to sit with me. I mentioned that I had seen him on Munchies, and we spoke of my longing for traditional french fare. I decided to stick with appetizers this evening (a bunch of them!) because I could indulge my cravings for the more traditional french offerings, but as Josh would say, with a bit of a modern twist. Just what the doctor ordered. Even though I was just having appetizers, the order in which they came to the table was carefully considered. Not all together, but in a measured, comfortable way. The sommelier came over to the table and reviewed what I was having and suggested a glass that would satisfy throughout all the dishes. I believe it was the Patrick Piuze Val De Mer Cremant de Bourgogne Rose - a burgundy from France. Wow. She was spot on. Ok, every single dish that came to the table was inspired and delicious. I mean really good. Seriously. There was escargot with toasted hazelnuts, chartreuse butter in pastry shells followed by pate de campagne - a traditional housemade pate with heritage pork, veal and pistachios. Next came the bone marrow au piovre - a peppercorn and remy martin vsop crusted bone marrow, burgundy onion jam with cornichons and grilled country bread. Right about then, Chef Josh sent over, as a wonderful surprise, the duck a l'orange - wood-grilled wings, cointreau glaze with sauce maltaise. But I wasn't done yet. I couldn't resist the prime steak tartare. What's fabulous about the steak tartare is that it is ground to order, with sauce verge, egg yolk and gaunter potatoes. Simply delicious. I gotta tell you that it was one of the finest meals I have ever had in Las Vegas. Just appetizers. Go figure.

Excellent food and service!!! 5 STARS!!!!! Phenomenal escargot appetizer, perfectly cooked beef and lamb. Friendly and knowledgeable sommelier and waitress and Chef Smith personally came out to greet us and ask us about our dining experience!

A+++++++
Amazing night! Shannon was the best server a person could have. We had the chefs choice menu and it was unreal!  Thanks again Shannon!!

(4) ~ very good overall food & service

DRINKS:
** Water(still) = (4) very good
* Caipirinha = (3.75) Good
* Espresso = (3.75) Good

FOOD:
** Waygu Bone Marrow = (5) Excellent!  Best I've had so far...
** Mac & Mimolette(cheese) = (4.25) Very good & Unique take on a Classic.
** French Baguette & Butter(Free) = (4) very good
* Double Cut Pork Chop = (3.75) Good & Smokey
* Chocolate Macaron = (3.25) pretty good, but it looked much better than it tasted, which tends to happen with pastries:(

Made our way here  for dinner on my wifey's birthday and had a great experience. 

We started with the formage plate with three different cheeses. It also came with a few other added on goodies that really went nicely with the toasted bread.

I had the double cut ribeye, which was marbeled  perfectly and cooked to perfection. She had the New York strip which was obviously a bit leaner but exactly what she wanted. The Charing on the steak was delicious and I went with the blue cheese fondue for a sauce on the steak. For the sides the hand cut fries and the mushroom dish that came on a croissant with a cream sauce really tasted spot on.

To drink the waitress was really helpful with helping us pick a couple full body Reds that went with these Choice cuts well. 
Good times!

Above and beyond service! This review is for service...not the food at Bardot. We were excited to try their king crab crepe and $25 bottomless rose deal, but we arrived at the restaurant to be told the exhaust hood over their stoves wasn't working, and they were cancelling all remaining reservations. The manager walked us over to Herringbone (also in Aria), explained the sitch to their manager, who said they would seat us and honor the rose special...nice touch! We enjoyed a fresh squeezed greyhound at the bar, before being seated in their outside patio, where we had a fabulous lunch. When the check came, our server told us that Bardot had covered our rose tab....WOW! Having to shut down dining on a Saturday afternoon is a restaurant's worst nightmare, but they still went the extra mile to make it up to their inconvenienced customers...definitely will go back next time I'm in Vegas! And Herringbone was awesome too!

Wow - Felt like we were in Paris.

Been here for dinner & brunch. Both were outstanding!
Truly delicious breakfast. Great service. Any place that gives you sliced bread and a jar of Foie Gras and calls it breakfast is tops on my list.

We went for brunch and I must say that my wife and I agree that this was the best meal we have ever had in Las Vegas.  We always eat family style, sharing dishes so we dan try more things. We started with the perfect tiny little escargo in puff pastry. I swear my wife could have died and gone yo heaven right then and there, except we were enjoing endless sparking French Rose wine way too much.

So we went on to the amaing buckwheat crepe with crab, and the one of a kind hunters waffle with duck confit and a sauce I cannot even describe it was so sumptious.  We also indulged, for $5, in the best French butter we have ever enjoyed, on crispy french baggette with sea salt we sprinkled on the buttered bread. OMG,

Perfect service, perfect food. Like everything in Vegas, it was an expensive brunch, but one we will never ever forget. We will return for dinner for certain.

I would recommend either Bardot Mon Ami gabi for brunch in Vegas.
Bardots portions are big so we shared the following amongst 4 girls:

- escargot bardot: comes in 4 small servings. Not as tasty as expected but still good
- endive and blue cheese salad: simple and delicious, blue cheese wasnt too overpowering
- petit french onion soup: perfect in every way
- french toast: basically half a loaf of high quality bread. Sooo full!

I will be back!! Next time I would try the nutella sticky buns...

Wonderful service once seated. Seafood tower was amazing. The most perfect crab and oysters. Their French press coffee was awesome. Our server was wonderful. They seated us 10 minutes after opening and seemed they were running a little behind. But then we asked for almond milk with coffee; they didn't have it but looked across the hotel to try to find some. Really above and beyond.

Would highly recommend this Bardot for a wonderful brunch.

So this is a brunch spot in the aria hotel I believe and honestly speaking it was just ok at best. Service was nice but super slow and my dishes were alright. I ordered the salmon benedict and I love the idea of using a croissant as a base but unfortunately the salmon was overcooked and not "smoked" at all. I also ordered the escargo which was super salty and I could really only taste the puff pastry surrounding the snail. Sad to say I won't be coming back here again for brunch.

A pricey but tasty upscale bistro option inside the Aria. The service is appropriately snooty, but the food is pretty good. Mussels came out cold, but were excellent when they came back. The appetizers and even fries were very delicious. The beer menu isn't huge, but the French and Belgian themed list is good for what is there. The wine list is extensive as well. The meat options are excellently cooked and seasoned as you might expect. Be prepared to spend a pretty penny though.

The bread and butter here was so amazing, I almost wanted to lick the butter out of the bowl but restrained myself. I really enjoyed the mussels in white wine sauce I had, it was a generous portion and the sauce was great for dunking more bread into. I can say the only thing I tried there that my palate didn't like was the french onion soup. I think the truffle oil didn't mix well or the bacon, but it was something that no one at my table would finish.

Me and my friend both left work and were hungry. I picked the hotel and we kinda wandered around until we found here. I was greeted by a polite host and we wanted to sit at the bar because we prefer there. They said open seating at the bar and we went in and nothing was open. We walked back and was quickly sat by the manager. The server Jesus was a pleasure. He was respectful and had a great personality. 

I had an incident where I cut my arm and sleeve on the sharp edge of the table. I told the host just as a precaution so it didn't happen to anyone else. I wasn't upset except that my sleeve ripped. The manager came over and was very empathetic and took care of the situation. He introduced himself but I forgot his name but he was a big help. They bought me and my friend dessert and coffee.

Best part about this meal was the food. I had the blood orange duck wings. I totally would pay more if they were bottomless :) my friend enjoy his perfectly cooked steak: the French fries were even great. Great job kitchen!

Def would come back here another time. Being a local I hope to be welcomed back :)

Went for brunch on a Saturday. Very different than most brunches I have been to because of the French influence. I got the sticky bun which they told me was a new item. It was very good but very sweet. I couldn't eat it all myself because it was so sweet so I had some of my friends hash browns. They were excellent. I also had champagne which was delicious. Service was good as was the decor.  I didn't do the unlimited rose wine but people seemed to be enjoying it. I've also been here for dinner and it was good too.

How I haven't reviewed this restaurant blows my mind considering it's been a staple for celebrations since their opening a few years ago. Valentine's Day, my birthday, and this week my mother's birthday are all experiences that have completely blown me away. The service here is stellar and the service staff always makes you feel welcome. 

I don't eat meat, but the orange duck wings looked amazing and was told the bearnaise that accompanies it was fantastic. I had the king crab crepe that comes serves on a buckwheat crepe with green apples and an over easy egg. This dish never ever disappoints. 

My mom ordered the sea bass which was presented beautifully and tasted amazing, while I had the super rich gnocchi but couldn't stop eating it. A glass of ruinart paired perfectly with the entrees. 

For dessert you have to order the mille feuille-- I promise you won't regret it.

Went with a group, 6 of us shared everything:
The bread- was divine
The butter- I want to bathe in it
The charcuterie- fabulous combo
The oysters- didn't try them, looked beautiful though 
The shrimp cocktail- large and luscious 
The duck wings- were phenomenal  
The escargot- in phyllo wow just wow
The flat iron steak and frites- superb 
The macaroni and cheese- how do they make it, so gorgeous 
The chicken- was amazing 
The tartare- was extremely needed. Not much good tartare in Vegas, they nailed it 
The wine list- excellent selection

Can't wait to go again!
AMAZING EVERYTHING is all i have to say. Bottomless rose? Um PLEASE!!!! Service is amazing, food is out of this world. I will be back to Bardot every time i am in Vegas, no doubt about it!

Oh wow. During my most recent three day stop in Vegas that included some of the city's finest - brunch at Bardot was hands down the highlight thanks to some of the best and most unique french toast I've ever had. 

Star 1: How were the service and atmosphere?

In a city of hour plus waits for brunch and all sorts of other ridiculousness, Bardot has kept the classic model intact, and I was easily able to secure a 10:15 brunch reservation for four the Saturday morning of a music festival weekend. Our party was seated immediately and the service was fast, friendly, and knowledgeable. Star Granted. 

Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?

Bardot isn't cheap, but honestly it was entirely more reasonable than what I was expecting. I ordered the absolutely massive sticky bun for the table as a starter, and while yes $16.00 is absurd when you're of the mindset that you can get something somewhat similar at Cinnabon for 30% of that, the quality here was noteworthy. 

For a better comparison, the Steakburger at Bardot is $19.00. That's above my $15.00 burger threshold but not by much.

My french toast, which could have comfortably fed two, came in at $19.00, which was entirely reasonable given the quality. Star Granted. 

Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?

My oh my. I've had some truly out of this world french toast in my day to include what came out of my own household as a child, but I'd never had anything that resembled the French Toast at Bardot.

While the massive block of bread was intimidating at first, I quickly realized that I could cut into it's buttery smooth texture with a quick swipe of the fork, and the airy texture was flawlessly combo'd with a butter-like whipping cream that I could have eaten all by itself and been perfectly happy. I'm not an almond guy, but the almond brittle and orgeat syrup went over well at the table, and all in all this was a truly stellar dish. Dual Stars Granted. 

Star 5: Would you eat here every day if you could?

I'll take Bardot over a Vegas buffet, or any other alternative, any day of the week. Star Granted.

Just ate here for brunch with my wife and we were both very impressed. Large portions, fair price, and gourmet dishes! I got the French toast and it was delicious with flavors of coconut, vanilla bean and toasted almonds. The French press coffee was strong and tasty. The presentation was perfect with a great wait staff that was attentive and pleasant. Wife got some French ham Benedict that she raved about. All fresh ingredients. Bacon is very thick cut and border lines on being slices of ham, regardless it was good. Orange juice was very fresh. Enough already, I'm sick of typing...just go there damn it!

Vraiment très bien!!

Some friends and I stopped in here around 6:30PM before a show on a Saturday night without reservations.  I was very busy inside, but there were some bar stools available near the open windows.  We pulled some together and our waitress very kindly had someone make us a table in the bar area so we could sit and eat in comfort.  

It was very beautiful inside and the service was fantastic.  Since we where crunched for time we only grabbed one glass of bubbly & the Charcuterie board. Everything on it was delicious.  The hazelnuts were my favorite thing of interest though.  And oh la la, that bread that was served was divine.  You could live on bread and wine alone in this place! (but what fun would that be)

My only regret was how quickly we had to devour our food and rush off.  I would certainly come back and plan to stay for a full dining experience next time.

We just had another amazing dining experience at a Michael Mina restaurant. This guy does not disappoint. We've been to his restaurants in Seattle, San Francisco, and now Vegas. 

We sat at our table and began perusing the menu. We had our eyes set on the tuna tartine appetizer when the waiter remembered to tell us about the tasting menu. Thank goodness she did because once we saw it we could not pass it up. 

We got the summer melon and tuna tartine to start. That was followed by gnocchi for the second course. For the third course we got the lamb and sole, followed by each of the two desserts. I have to say I'm usually apprehensive about cherry desserts, but I loved the bing cherry clafouti. We wine paired the menu and were not disappointed. 

This was a very classy restaurant and the food was phenomenal!

Another great brunch.  No where else in Vegas can you get authentic French cuisine with bottomless.This time I went with croque madame.  Amazing bread, goeey goodness, and runny egg.  Not much more you can do to impress me at a restaurant. The bubbles keep goinan the wait staff is always helpful and doesn't force you to finish the meal.  I love brunch so much and on the strip this is a top 3 no doubt

I went here with 8 other guys for a bachelor party. We asked for the prefixed menu and got hooked up. $130 a person with a decent tip literally will never eat anything as satisfying for the rest of my life! If you aren't familiar with French food still give it a try. The best duck, beef, pork , salmon, escargot I've ever tried 5/5

We had reservations and high hopes! We got in so fast even with a line! Though, once inside...the wait started. Just to get our waitress and a glass of water it took 15 minutes. Our waitress was a nice pregnant girl, and have only little complaints about her.  She was quiet, so quiet I could barely hear her over the incredible noise. We did tapas, ordering 8 appetizers. Shrimp cocktail was perfectly cooked and tender. The cheese plate was delicious. The meat plate, half yummy half flavorless.  The duck lorange was not to my taste, though others said it was just ok. The pigs ear turned my stomach, but I had a small price that was totally fat, the men ate the rest. My sister spit her piece out. The seared foie gras was yummy, the parfait foie gras was delicious! King crab crepe was yummy!  The worst part the bread was burnt, ard and inedible. Which made it hard to eat most of the appetizers, as most required some sort of delivery device. 
All the desserts were amazing
The manager came over and spoke to us, and apologized, though didn't offer any discount or compensation. So don't expect any thing more than " I'm sorry, you didn't enjoy the meal." Which is fine, we didn't need a discount or freebies. But with the amount of food sent back it would have been nice.
And it would have been nice of the waitress was a little more attentive.

Ooh La La, it is wonderful to have Michael Mina's French brasserie at Aria's! I enjoyed having a nice time there!  

Ambience 5: welcoming lounge filled with lively guests laughing and chatting while sipping at their drinks ... wowed when I was led to their oh so inviting dining room ... finishing were the more casually dressed and gatherings of families with young children from early seatings ... very popular place for big parties ... and, when the night moved on, stylishly dressed guests swaggered in!

Service 3.5: warm, funny, and personable was our waiter ... was rushed in finishing the first shared appetizer before having the second appetizer appeared, the table top just can't fit both plates; otherwise, the pacing was perfect the rest of the evening ... sommelier came to table at the start but never came back after I had decided what my entree to be as requested!

Food 3.75: their bone marrow with red wine onion jam AND their generous portion of seared foie gras were delicious ... I loved their warm beets & goat cheese tossed in a fantastic vinaigrette ... unfortunately, their lamb crown roast was a total disappointment - turned off I was with how much fat was left on the lamb!

Instead of dinner reservations next time, I'll be back at Bardot's lounge for their signature cocktails and bubblies with an hors d'oerves or two!

Cheers!

Our favorites of the night were the king crab crepe and rib eye with the Bordelaise sauce. The oak smoked Duroc pork chop tasted great but was too dry and disappointed a bit. We also had the mille feuille for dessert which was very good.

Our favorite dish of the night was the king crab crepe. My wife really liked the taste of the buckwheat crepe which was pretty good by itself. The crepe was topped with king crab, trumpet mushrooms, a sunny-side egg and a waiter-poured beurre blanc sauce. The dish worked as a whole, was flavorful and was a great way to start the meal.

We ordered the rib eye steak frites since this was a brasserie, and it was mighty tasty. The fries were crispy on the outside and soft on the inside, paired with a tasty garlic aoli. The fries were good by themselves and apparently cooked in beef fat, but they were also good with the garlic aoli. The rib eye was also pretty tasty, not as good as dry aged rib eye from a steak house like Mastro's, but still pretty good by itself. While the rib eye was great by itself, it was even better with the Bordelaise sauce. 

The oak smoked Duroc pork chop tasted a bit like bacon, given that it was smoked and salty. While the taste was great, unfortunately, it was very dry. This was the most disappointing thing about the dinner. Otherwise, the pork chop was served with bacon, some root vegetables and slices of cornichon. 

Our waiter recommended the mille feuille for dessert, and it was a great way to end the meal. Essentially, the mille feuille is made of layers of thin caramelized puff pastry sheets separated by vanilla pastry cream (creme patisserie). The difference in texture between the delicately crispy puff pastry sheets and the soft pastry cream really worked. The dessert was sweet but not overly so and was surprisingly good.

Overall, everything was flavorful and well-executed for the most part, with the exception of the pork chop. However, even with that slight misstep, we would come back if we were in the mood for French brasserie cuisine.

I absolutely love this place!  The food was good, the service was great, the ambiance was intimate, but similar looking to a pub.  

Their menu has great selections.  I couldn't decided between the escargots, foie gras, or bone marrow, but after some thinking, I decided to go with the bone marrow.  That was a great choice!

I've had bone marrow elsewhere.  In some places, I've gotten bone that are large but with little marrow.  This one had smaller bones, but generous portions of marrow! The bone marrow comes in two pieces and 3 slices of toasted bread.  You use the marrow to spread on the bread...like butter and yes, better than butter!!  If it's your first time having bone marrow ever, or if you're not a fan of the bone marrow taste itself, I'd recommend using the side of caramelized onions.  The caramelized onions will take over the bone marrow taste.

Got the mussels for the entree.  The light garlic buttery wine sauce was flavorful, and it didn't feel too buttery.  The only disappointment was the size of the mussels.  I'm used to large jumbo mussels almost as big as oysters, but these mussels were just slightly bigger than clams.  Regardless, they tasted excellent.  

I'd like to come back to try the escargots and the foie gras!

After we experienced our brunch here, we completely understand why it was rated 4.5 stars. All the dishes we ordered was fantastic. 
1)We love the escargot here, it's the best so far, although it's only 4 small ones, each bit was awesome, you can completely enjoy the escargot in your mouth. 
2) French onion soup was very flavorful. We love how rich the cheese on top but not heavy. The soup contained onions and toasts. Good combination 
3) chicken French dip was amazing. The dipping was rich but not heavy. We had beef French dip before, but this one was very creative 
4) smoked salmon croissant Benedict. The poached egg was good. 

Service was not as good. Not as attentive. 

Overall, good experience for brunch.

I celebrated my birthday here. We had 10 people in our party. We loved everything we ordered and we ordered a lot. Service here is wonderful and they even gave me a birthday card and a dessert (maybe my friends paid). This was my favorite restaurant in Vegas. Really loved their dessert martinis too. Will definitely come back. Thank you for making my birthday so special.

I am a huge fan of Bardot for dinner and believe they offer one of the best, if not the best Brunch in Las Vegas. I was informed of a special dinner where they flew in a renowned Chef from the UK (Calum Franklin) to team up with their Executive Chef (who has also won awards) to prepare a special feast that what seemed to me was a meal fit for the royal family. It was my best meal I've had all year with a wine pairing that fit perfect. Desserts were presented to share and everyone couldn't believe their eyes and how they scaled up the portions. An outstanding sold out event and can't wait for the next one!

We brought a party of 20 here for a rehearsal dinner and it was a great experience. Very attentive service. The food was excellent. We chose between chicken, steak, and fish - everyone loved the entrees. Appetizers included escargot, duck wings l'orange, and charcuterie board. They were all fantastic. I also had the "enhanced" french onion soup and was not disappointed. If you're looking for a casual french steak/seafood option this place is great.

Love love the food. Came here for a bachelorette dinner with 11 other ladies. Everything was so scrumptious, but it was just too much food. We could've done a 3 course meal and it would've been more than enough. But I guess it's Vegas, so go big or go home. 

1st course consists of family style appetizers: charcuterie board, duck wings a l'orange and escargot Bardot. 

2nd- I ordered shrimp cocktail and a friend of mine ordered steak tartare. Normally not a big fan of steak tartare, but this was delicious. 

3rd- I got the rack of lamb which just melted in my mouth. It was so so tender and bloody, the way I like my meat. 

4th- dessert trio (creme brûlée, chocolate macaron and profiteroles)

Came here at 5 for happy hour. Turns out no more HH deal on food. Beer is still $5 and the specialty drink is $7. Also they don't serve regular food til 6pm. Sucks for us because we had to leave at 6 to catch a flight. Didn't get to try the food but service was good. Minus one star for not having any deal on food for hh.

**FANTASTIC DINNER IN LAS VEGAS**

ABOUT
======
Classic French brasserie experience offering traditional brasserie fare by Michael Mina.
Located inside the Aria.

AMBIANCE
=========
Feels of dining at a Parisian café but with a modern craft kitchen.
Dressy casual.

FOOD
=====
FOIE GRAS PARFAIT - $18
Ruby port gelée with grilled country bread was the highlight of the meal.
Beautiful and high quality. The fluffy taste is unbelievably good.
Can't stop thinking about it and came back the next day for it.
RATING: 5/5

ESCARGOTS BARDOT - $18
These wild burgundy snails with toasted hazelnuts, chartreuse garlic butter and puff pastry shells were surprisingly different and wonderfully delicious.
RATING: 4.5/5

BONE MARROW AU POIVRE - $17
The peppercorn-crusted bone marrow with burgundy onion jam and a side of grilled country bread was OK. Not as fatty and scrumptious as I would like.
RATING: 3.5/5

MUSSELS MARINIÈRES* 29
These Prince Edward island mussels, in garlic butter, dolin vermouth, 
and tarragon were juicy and tasty. The warm baguettes came in handy for the broth.
RATING: 4/5

MACARONI & MIMOLETTE GRATINÉE - $13
My least favorite dish. Not as traditional American as I would like,
but it's French, so I get it. 
Not gooey. A bit on the dry side.
RATING: 3/5

DESSERTS - $13 each
=========
MILLE FEUILLE
My favorite! Caramelized puff pastry layered with vanilla crème pâtissière.
Classic and excellent.
RATING: 5/5

CHOCOLATE MACARON
French chocolate cookie with Valrhona chocolate mousse
can be shared. It's big and very chocolatey.
RATING: 4/5

CRÈME BRÛLÉE
Vanilla bean custard and turbinado croquant were OK.
Wasn't the best I've had, but solid.
RATING: 3.5/5

BEVERAGE - ~$15
=========
CLASSIC VODKA MARTINI
Done perfectly, thank you.
RATING: 5/5

APEROL SPRITZ
Also done perfectly.
RATING: 5/5

PRO TIP
======
Look into their Everlasting Rosé during brunch for $20
(Saturday & Sunday | 10:00 a.m. - 2:00 p.m.)
Heard their Nutella Sticky Bun, Croissant Benedicts, and Hunter's Waffle
were killers.

OVERALL
========
One of my favorite dining experiences in Vegas.
Good for groups and dates.

HIGHLY RECOMMEND.
The pate was amazing.  I also had the pork chop which was a hit.  Service was fantastic.  I'll be back here soon.

Shady rolled in to Michael Mina's newest outpost in Aria for the first of 6 meals in his latest Vegas boondoggle. Shady and guest started with a nice bottle of Rose' and moved on to the meal. 
First off, the space is beautiful. A stunning bar greets you as moved towards the dining area. After a long perusal, Shady's gracious companion lusted for the seared foie gras, while Shady himself opted for the Duck wings L'orange. The foie gras was delicious, and was consumed immediately. The Duck was indeed delicious, but far too much work finding meat among the bones. As good as they were, Shady would order something else in the future.
 On to the mains-The Lupe De Mer-Seabass was outstanding. Its hard to say it was better than the perfectly cooked Duroc pork chop, but with both being 4 stars, the nod goes to the seabass. A side of sprouts, some rest, then off to dessert. Another outstanding dish-The frozen Paris brest. Basically the most delicious saucers u can imagine. 
The French fare was the perfect start to the Vegas binge. The service was great, the scene upscale bistro, and the food outstanding. Shady will have to revisit for the much heralded brunch. Bill was 273$ with the bottle, and includes Shadys signature bountiful tip.

Haven't had mediocre food combined with a long wait, and bad service in a long time. Not only was it bad enough that the food was late over one hour, but it also wasn't up to par. On top of that, the server didn't take instructions very well, didn't manage our expectations, and was at one point, nowhere to be found. I waited a few days to write this review, hoping that I'd be more fair, so here it is, my fair review. We went during brunch on a Sunday, and if you must go, then have their pastry bowl and tartare, which was about the only items that were decent.

Have been wanting to try Bardot since I saw the ads for it during summer time. Long story short did not disappoint at all. The courses were timed perfectly, the service was amazing and helped make the meal. Onto the food every course was great a must try would be the duck wings and the chocolate macaron for dessert.

Beautiful restaurant! The food is very good as well and the service is great. We had so many lovely dishes but I would say that my favorite would be the escargot with chartreuse butter. So good! Can't wait to come back.

This review is for their 2016 Las Vegas Restaurant Week $80 menu.

Bardot is both a solid brunch and dinner spot. The food is delectable, and the service is unpretentious. 

The three-course Las Vegas Restaurant Week menu may be more than enough food, but I'd suggest ordering an extra appetizer or two to share.

Appetizer - Escargots Bardot: Can't stand the sight of SNAILS? Well, these are wrapped in a puff pastry. These are savory, buttery, and delicious -- you can't eat just one. 

Appetizer - Seared Foie Gras Lyonnaise: If you've ever tried Filipino-style adobo, the sauce in this dish has a familiar adobo flavor to me. I wasn't a fan of the beluga lentils, but I liked the combination of foie gras and the prune confiture. 

First Course - King Crab Crepe: A crab and black trumpet mixture folded into a buckwheat crepe with a sunny side egg right in the center. Yum.

Second Course - Maine Lobster Thermidor: Truthfully, I'm not a fan of lobster, but I gave this a try any way and it was delicious. This was my first time trying this dish, and it reminded  me of a "dynamite" that you can order at some Japanese restaurants. I loved the mixture of the mushrooms, bernaise sauce, and the tender chunks of lobster meat. The creamy mashed potatoes were bomb; I wish I had a bowl of just that on the side. 

Third Course - Chocolate Macaron: Rich and decadent. This is a deluxe version of a regular macaron. Sandwiched in between chocolate cookies were dollops of chocolate mousse. Chocolate sauce and chocolate shavings topped it off. 

For French cuisine on The Strip, Bardot's my top pick. I cannot wait to return.

We came here for our anniversary dinner and loved it! We were greeted for our reservation with a cute signed card from the staff congratulating us. 

We had made the *mistake* of eating at Wicked Spoon for brunch earlier in the day, so we didn't get to try as many menu items at Bardot as we wanted to (glutton problems). We ordered cocktails to start, the Crowd Pleaser for him and Death in the Florida Straights for me. Both were excellent, I wanted to order 5 more of mine, because the spiciness was divine, but we had a show later I needed to be awake for. 

We skipped appetizers, and he got the Heritage Chicken Roti and I had the filet mignon with steak frîtes. Ooooh man. My steak was a perfect rare, and so juicy tender perfect. The fries are cooked in beef fat and are pure decadence with mayonnaise. My husband was in love with his chicken, and we heard our waiter tell another table they were out of it as we were eating, so try not to miss it! 

The restaurant itself is gorgeously decorated, and while we were sitting at a center table, it still felt quite intimate and romantic. Our waiter was great, and struck the perfect balance of attentive and unobtrusive. 

By this point we were stuffed, which was a heartbreak, because I wanted to try their entire dessert menu. Truly, though, it gives us an excuse to come back on our next visit-- not that we really needed one.

Oh Bardot how I love thee. Honestly the best food I have enjoyed in Vegas. Excellent and friendly service and am absolutely FAB happy hour until 7pm. The apps were so incredible we never made it to an entree and repeated the same meal a few days later.

Our favorite dishes...
Prime Tartar 
Foie Gras with lentils (so good order your own so you don't have to share, trust me)
Bone marrow
Duck wings

Also the French 75 with gin was excellent and so refreshing.

The vibe is polished and classy but also warm and welcoming. Not a spot to bring your kids. Find it on the 2nd promenade level in Aria.
Exceptional! Everything was perfect!  Matthew was a great waiter and our food and drinks were delicious. Very large portions too, which made the prices seem reasonable for Vegas.

This review is for their happy hour menu which is on point. The quality of the ingredeints shine and you get what you pay for. In a hoity toity hotel and a high end restaurant, this is quite hard to come by. The service was excellent and, for a family of four dressed in casual wear, we were treated no different than the business suits sitting a table next to us.

The highlights include the baguette with salted butter that our family ate with joy. Yes its complimentary but its darn good too.

We ordered the poutine, the beef tartare, and three different tartines. Everything was good, but my favorite was the beef tartine. Reduced in red wine and served on a crispy tartine, they crack a hella fresh egg in top and what you get is pure awesomeness.

I don't get the opportunity to eat at an establishment like this, but when im glad that my experience here was a good one.

Gorgeous bar and the interior is so French, I just adore it. 

Excellent service. I had the la varenne cocktail (cognac, liqueur, lemon juice), bone marrow au poivre appetizer, poulet roti entree with mushroom bread pudding and haricots verts, and frozen paris brest for dessert. My fiance had the pork chop. 

La varenne was a little too sweet and not strong enough. The caramelized onions that came with the bone marrow was a little too salty, but the country bread was perfect. The paris brest should probably be more of the traditional variety, as opposed to with hazelnut ice cream, as the ice cream hardened the choux pastry and made it less enjoyable altogether. 

A little bit of a limited menu.
Great brunch, lobster Benedict was super tasty, not on the menu but they can make it when you ask! Unlimited rose for $25 was amazing! Will definitely return next time I am in Vegas.
Classic classy restaurant.  The service was nice and professional.  The Hunters Waffles were the best food I had in Vegas.  Highly recommended breakfast.

This was a front of house and a back of house fail. Service: 8 min wait for water plus an additional 6 min to see a menu. So if you're keeping track that's a 14 min wait to just see the menu. Add another 8 min if you want a drink from the bar.   The seats were hard and uncomfortable. 
I see the lack of a gluten-free menu as a front of house problem because it puts an additional burden on the back of house. 
Very limited menu. 
The foie terrine was not to my taste. The pork chop was very undercooked. Unacceptable. You cannot serve undercooked pork to your guests. Instant one star.

What was once a beautiful, rustic space with American Fish has been transformed into a lavish and elegant interior every bit equal to the $5 million they spent to renovate. They made this new Michael Mina spot more inviting and approachable by moving the bar to the front of the restaurant and added a small patio area. The impressive kitchen remains unchanged. Large windows encasing it allows diners a great view into the heart of the restaurant.

Many of the appetizers we sampled were stellar, particularly the pate de campagne ($13), foie gras parfait ($15), and blue crab crepe ($16). The port gelée topping the parfait was just sweet enough to balance the savoriness of the creamy foie. Less successful dishes included the escargots Bardot ($17), which I found to be too salty and garlic-heavy, and the tarte flambée ($14).

If you dine there for brunch, the Hunter's waffle ($19) and croque madame ($18) are both solid dishes, but French toast ($12) is a must. Despite it's impressive size, the thick cut brioche was surprisingly light and airy, even with the interior retaining much of the custard it was soaked in.

Of the savory dishes we tried the Heritage chicken roti ($29) was a standout with it's crispy skin and well seasoned meat. The Parisian gnocchi ($23) was beautifully presented with it's mix of pillowy soft pasta, mushrooms, and goat cheese.

Despite splitting the dishes with four other people most of us were stuffed. That didn't stop us from getting dessert. The mille feuille ($12) and apple tarte tatin ($12) were both excellent, but the chocolate macaron ($12) was my favorite. The crispy macaron shell, smooth chocolate cream in the center, sprinkling of salt and warm chocolate sauce poured table-side make it a chocoholic's dream come true.

Michael Mina restaurants can be hit or miss, but he's got a winner with this one. His team has taken a rather ho-hum brasserie concept and given it new life. With a mix of traditional and new dishes, it has the potential to attract many to French cuisine for the first time or a return visit.

Wow is the word!  So we arrived and we're going to be seated in the dinning room, but ended up staying at the bar. Don't let this fool you! Great experience and amazing service form all the staff and managers. Bardot food and signature cocktails for sure are meant to be remembered.   We started with the Escargot Bardot which was so delicious that you don't want to stop eating!  It's a puff pastry made to perfection! 
Foie Gras Parfait....wow!!! I'm not a huge fan of Foie Gras, but this was so good I seriously could not have enough. I'm sure my dinner partner was not happy since he loves it and I usually let him eat it all... Not this time!  It's a ruby port gelee and grilled country bread.  Another must have !
Duck A L'Orange- ( duck wings)  grilled wings, blood orange , sauce maltaise. cooked perfectly and just enough to keep you happy.  
Charcuterie Board- it's super delicious and definitely a good dish to order if you have kids or picky eaters.  Looks like a flat bread pizza but taste like a million bucks! Very unique taste  housemade pate, heritage pork rillete and ham amazing. 
Onion Soup with all the fixings was very tasty! Nothing to write home about, but if you like onion soup for sure a good choice ! 
 Cocktails..... Well don't mind if I do!  lost Generation is a flavor of the old amazing flavors of what a conga cocktail should be. Great balance !  Also the The Ritz was   Very tasty and  "And God created  woman" was a great choice .  This place is a must visit when at Aria !  Overall Chef Mina does an amazing job  and i lol forward to coming by again to visit and try some other dishes as well as some wines !

LAMB CHOPS. The best I've ever had. Perfectly cooked and laid on top of a bed of cooked greens. You get a full rack for the price which is more than what more places offer. The atmosphere is romantic and the service was great.

I was initially disappointed when American Fish closed down, being a big fan of the happy hour they offered. I will say that disappointment was eased when I walked into Bardot Brasserie for brunch one day with the ladies. 

Home to the Everlasting Rose, this is brunch on another level. This brunch is elevated. Rose is one way to stand out on Champagne Sunday! There's lots of light, and there's some wonderful dishes including croissant benedicts in lobster and surf & turf varieties. 

For a decadent French onion soup, try adding the périgord truffle, braised short rib & poached egg. It's mouthwateringly good.
We enjoyed our dinner at BARDOT, the pork chops are a must. Oscar is the best waiter we've experienced. BARDOT is our new go to place when we come to Las Vegas.

One of the most unique experiences ever! We had the chefs choice where they selected everything for us. It was a 6 course meal that turned out to be like 15 and we al got different things! We were pleasantly surprised and stuffed, def recommend!!

This is for the Happy Hour, and what a good Happy Hour it was.  I had decided to try the HH for my birthday and at the last minute invited a couple of friends as well.  We sat at the bar (hooks below the bar to hang your coat/purse) and had to wait a little before we could order since they start the HH exactly at 5pm and not a minute before.  The bartender was really good about letting my friend sample the different beers and cider on tap and we all wound up with the Ommegang Witte to start while waiting for 5pm.  

Once we were able we ordered the duck wings, shrimp cocktail, bone marrow, fries, both tartes, and the macaroni au gratin to share.  The wings were a big hit and we wound up ordering more of those.  The tartes were also great; so simple but so delicious.  Neither of my friends wanted to try the bone marrow but that was alright because it was wonderful and I was happy to have its deliciousness all to myself.  The drink of the day was the Bee's Knees made with gin, honey syrup, and lemon and it also was delicious.  You may see a theme here.

The fries, macaroni, and shrimp cocktail were all good but nothing out of the ordinary taste wise.  The garlic mayo with the fries was really good, though.
