Before I give a review, ask to be served by the waiter named Steve from the Ivory Coast.  He is the greatest living waiter on Earth.  When God created the greatest waiter on Earth, he made him of French Lebanese descent and he sprung out from the Cote d'ivoire.

This place replaced the missed American Fish, another Michael Mina spot.  This haunt is Mina's take on French food (greatest in the world).  The bar itself is worth in the millions.  No penny was spared creating this place and Michael's wife can be seen here every so often.

All salads and soups are solid orders.  Many of the apps are near top notch.  But what anyone cares about are the main courses.

The flank steak is ELITE.  The ribeye and all other steaks I have eaten all rate a 8 or more out of 10.  The sides are a bit too small for sharing for more than two people.  The mushrooms side is more of a pastry than a mushroom dish  Asparagus and brussel sprouts sides are really good, totally French style.  Fish dishes all rate a 8 out of 10. I had the cod, salmon and sea bass and to me reverse the order I just stated for taste and quality.

All deserts are high end.  I recommend the banana desert.

All cocktails are of high quality and all have a special flare to them.  Heck, all the dudes behind the bar are friendly, ready to serve, want to talk to you and have no heirs.

~ Happy Hour Review ~ 
If you're looking for an elegant and decadent meal for a reduced price, I highly recommend checking out Bardot Brasserie's Happy Hour menu served daily from 5-7 pm. For under $60, my boyfriend and I ordered four things off the menu (and a cocktail!) Everything we ordered tasting amazing and the atmosphere felt super classy. We stopped by at the start of HH still in our day clothes and felt very underdressed compared to some of the patrons at the bar. We still received great service, regardless of how we were dressed, but if you're the type to dress up, definitely bring your A game when you come here! All the guys and gals I saw at the bar were decked out in suits and evening gowns. 

We ordered salmon tartare, steak tartare, a tartine, and a burger. The salmon tartare tasted fresh and light. I especially loved the taste of the chive mascarpone with capers on the top. I'm not normally a fan of the salty, almost fishy-like taste of capers, but the creamy richness of the mascarpone helped to balance everything out. The steak tartare (ground to order!) not only looked super aesthetically appealing, but the richness of the yolk with the perfectly seasoned ground prime steak was simply divine. My boyfriend, however, mentioned that he didn't like the sauce verte drizzled on the top, as it tasted a bit too rich and pungent for his preference. We also ordered a tartine (open-faced sandwich) with grilled shrimp and saffron roullie. The shrimp was cooked perfectly and the garlic-y roullie really gave the shrimp the "oomf" I was looking for. The bread here is also great. I believe it's baked in house. Also, as a side note - you get free bread and butter as an appetizer. And OMG - the butter here is out of this world. Butter is always awesome, but this butter is something really special. It's so spreadable, creamy, salty, and rich! Best butter I've ever had. Seriously. 

But the true highlight of this already amazing meal? The le steakburger, made with a prime rib patty. Yup, you read that right. Prime rib. So flavorful and so, so juicy. The nuttiness of the comte cheese along with a generous spread of garlic aioli on the top just made this burger seriously next level shiz. If I recall, this was the most expensive thing that we ordered (I believe about $19), but it was so worth it. This was arguably the best burger of my life - and I've had a lot of great burgers.

Thanks to Bardot Brasserie for a dining experience that this foodie will remember forever!

HANDS DOWN THE BEST FRENCH TOAST I'VE EVER HAD IN MY LIFE!  It is pillowy soft heaven on a plate.  Apparently, they soak the massively thick cut brioche in their custard mixture overnight to get it so moist and delicious!  It is so creamy yet light in texture and not too sweet.  You may not even need to spread that dollop of vanilla mascarpone but it is loaded with vanilla bean--yum!  It certainly adds more decadent richness to the dish.  The French toast is set off quite nicely with crunchy almond brittle.  It is also paired with an orgeat (almond) syrup, which just adds another flavor layer to the party...but honestly, the French toast on its own is superb!  This is definitely a must have if dining here for brunch.  I also added the double cut bacon (pork belly fans will love this) and poached eggs which were cooked perfectly.  It turned out to be a lot of food so next time I'll just have the French toast with the bacon!  Service and ambiance were great as well.  Can't wait to try Bardot for dinner next time we're in Vegas.

Slave girl and I were looking for a place to get brunch and we found out Bardot Brasserie had brunch until 1:30pm with bottomless mimosa. Yes please. 

Bardot was beautifully decorated and very well lighted inside. The bar was very busy especially with bottomless mimosa.

We ordered steak tartare, truffle fries, French toast, and croque madame.

We started with complimentary baguette with salted butter. I know nothing about how to make butter magical, but the butter that came with was really good especially the part had salt on. I tried to use regular table salt and they just didn't taste the same. 

Steak tartare was excellent. The steak was grounded to order mixing with sauce verte and egg yolk. Severed with gaufrette potato chips. It had creamy texture and good flavor. 

Croque madame came with pain de mie, Paris ham, gruyere fondue, and a organic egg on top. It was good but it didn't wow me like the one I had in San Francisco. 

Slave girl told me the French toast was one of the best she ever had. Since I only had a bite, I would say sure, why not. It came with brioche French toast top with vanilla mascarpone, almond brittle, and organic syrup. 

Truffle fries was a bit fail in my book. Sure it was done well, but I didn't get too much of truffle flavors which defeated the purpose of "truffle" fries. 

The service here was fantastic. It was a full house but my mimosa was never empty. Matter of fact, it was filled before I even finished the glass. On top of that, our server was also training a new server too. Great job for sure. We will go back to try the dinner menu.

Visited this restaurant while staying at the Aria. Everything was pretty expensive but taste pretty good. Decent atmosphere and excellent service. If price is not an issue, I would definitely come visit more often.

Definitely not traditional french. They need to be clear about this being a twist on french type food items with American flavors.  The French onion soup was delicious but the sole was lacking flavor. And don't get me started on our escargot wrapped in puff pastry. All you taste is the pastry no escargot in sight or taste. Birthday dinner wasn't what I thought it was going to be. Came saw and disappointed.

My first time at a Michael Mina establishment and it was memorable.

I loved Bardot upon entry, we had a minor reservation snafu but the host quickly was able to take care of us. Bardot is sexy, chic with an easy sophistication. My senses were quickly stimulated and I quickly was enraptured in a laissez-faire attitude while thinking of what cocktail to have.

In my group, I had (forgive me for not having the exact names) Salmon with Beluga Lentils, started with an Endive Salad, and Lemon Meringue Tart for dessert. Salmon was robust and rich, and the Endive Salad balanced the strong flavors of the bleu cheese and endive perfectly in it's vinaigrette.

But that Lemon Meringue Tart? I'm still dreaming of it. It was THAT good.

If they offer you bread and butter here, definitely get it. That baguette is served perfectly warm and that butter is creamy.

Michael Mina isn't that everyday occasion, but I'll definitely find a reason to come back here!

The only disappointment was having a few glasses of rose and not finding a photo of Brigitte anywhere! Dommage.

After going to Michael Mina great restaurant RN74 in San Francisco I was hoping for same result here . The overall experience was disappointing . The restaurant is beautiful but found the food disappointing . My salad was a non descript mess . The rest of my dates and I food was forgettable The waiter would disappear for long stretches of time . 2 hours after this forgettable experience the pleasant manager called me to inform me that my credit card wasn't swiped properly and I owed for dinner . Lol. They should have comped me for this 
.You can only go by your own experience as I am sure on another night it would have been better . Unfortunately there will not be a next time .
Bardot has the best brunch ever!!!!  Great tasting pastries and such an elegant atmosphere.  Will definitely come back when in Vegas!

BEST. FRENCH. TOAST. EVER. Came to Bardot on New Year's Day in definite need of some carbohydrates after NYE on the strip. Our waiter was extremely kind and charismatic, despite the rather long wait for items. Restaurant is beautiful, with perhaps one of the most beautiful bars on the strip. Everyone enjoyed their food tremendously. For those who enjoy bread and butter, definitely recommend the beurre déchiré. SO tasty. The eggs Benedict, burger, croque madame and hunter's waffle were all extremely tasty. The real star of the show however was their french toast. My husband will usually never eat french toast, waffles or pancakes without extra syrup. The almond/orange syrup offered with the meal made him forget what table syrup was! Only regret we had was not having big enough stomachs to also order the Nutella sticky bun. Next time!!!
We end there for brunch yesterday.... Absolutely amazing, from Decor and the open space sitting.... Food are Delish!!!! And they have $20 bottomless rose, definitely will be back again

Excellent restaurant and service.  I was taken care of in the bar area, but the server (Rosie) was fantastic.  She was considerate, knowledgeable and complimentary of my menu choices. The Sommelier, Andrew, came over when I was reviewing the wine list and was incredibly knowledgeable.  He offered a perfect pairing and was very personable.  Kudos to the team in the restaurant, everyone from beginning to end was first class and perfect.

My fiancé surprised me with dinner at BARDOT Brasserie and I was so happy he did! Michael Mina's French brasserie in the Aria is a beautiful addition to a beautiful hotel. The restaurant is decorated with beautiful Parisian decor that makes you feel like you're away from the crazy city that is Las Vegas. Everything from the bar to the kitchen is absolutely beautiful.

We started off with a glass of wine and the steak tartare. Yum! We honestly loved it so much, we almost had a second order.

When it came down to the entrees, I went for the Lobster and my fiancé ordered the Lamb Rack. Beautiful presentation and best of all, it was delicious! I had a bite of the lamb rack and was instantly jealous of my fiancé's order. My lobster was yummy too, however, the next time I am ordering the brandy cream on the side. 

Finally, the server (who was excellent btw), insisted on dessert and coffee. We went straight for the giant chocolate macaroon (one word = HEAVEN) and had some cappuccinos. Absolutely delicious! The macaroon was perfection. I honestly could have had two more orders, if I wasn't so stuffed from everything else.

Overall, if you're looking for great service and a delicious meal, hit up BARDOT Brasserie.

It was fine.  Very good service, very good cocktails, fair food, good ambience.  Excellent beer and wine selection.  Food took quite some time to come out, we were there for about two hours and we did not stay for dessert.  

I really liked the place, it's just that the food itself was disappointing.

Came here with my girlfriend for her birthday bc we wanted to try at least one gourmet restaurant and I love French food. 

Great decor, very brasserie/French feeling. It was bougie and anything but pretentious, the people at the table next to us were in fanny packs (blast from the past much?)

We started by splitting a French onion soup (my first not counting what they serve at Panera) and it was deliciously indulgent. The melted Gruyere was to die for, and overall very flavorful. 

My girlfriend ordered the cod/bass (I forget which one but I'm too lazy to look it up) and I tried hers, it was quite excellent. Me, I'm a fan of a perfectly cooked roast chicken and I was served just that here. My only gripe was that the Au jus/drippings served on the side, the server poured it all over my chicken rather than letting me do it myself. Hence my bird was on the saltier end, more than I would like, but it was not unpleasant in the slightest. 

The biggest surprise was the mushroom bread pudding which came with my chicken. I didn't think two things such as mushrooms and bread pudding could be combined so deliciously but they were. My girlfriend hates Mushrooms but even she was floored by how good it tasted. 

The portions are gigantic btw so just be warned. I didn't think I could ever feel defeated by a meal but my gut was stuffed beyond doubt when I hit the 3/4th mark. My girlfriend threw in the towel much earlier so as such, neither of us could enjoy the dessert menu. However in our food coma states, we were not so secretly staring down the Mille feuille that the fanny pack folks were digging into next to us bc it looked delicious.

I went back to Bardot and had another great experience!!  Bardot isn't just good, it is phenomenal!  It is the little things that make it such a cool experience.  I highly recommend that you get the basket of Pastries for Brunch.  They look a little pricey, that is until you taste them.  I lived in Germany for a couple years and have been to Paris.  These were hands down the best I have ever had.  I am including a picture this time.  Even the Butter is great and they claim it is the best in the world!  I'm not going to argue with them.  I also really enjoyed the Duck Waffles again and the Hash Browns were also great.  The best thing we tried this time though was the giant Chocolate Macaron!!!  I love Bardot and I will be back any time I get the chance and it has really made me want to check out all of Michael Mina's restaurants!

beautiful place, with just right portions (albeit a little pricey). Have been 3x: twice during dinner and once during rose brunch - where the servers NEVER let my glass become under half full with rose!!! Same applies to my water glass! The service was supreme. The side of hash browns is delicious and so was the french toast that we all shared (several portions). There is a slight dress code for gentlemen so check on that - we came to booze it up right before Life is Beautiful festival so had to tell the guys no festival wear until after rose brunch ;)

The restaurant is located inside of the Aria hotel in Las Vegas, and it can be somewhat difficult to locate. It's a very casual, French restaurant, but their ambiance and bar-like atmosphere makes it quite the experience. We came at around 6pm with a reservation for four, and the table we were seated at was spacious and comfortable. The waiters were very kind, and brought us water and french baguettes to start with. The baguettes were very fresh, warm and soft on the inside while crunchy on the outside. 

We decided to skip out on the appetizers, and order entrees. We ordered a double cut rib eye, the lamb chops, and a pork chop. My brother and dad both ordered the double cut rib eye, but my dad's steak cooked medium had more flavor than my brother's steak cooked medium rare. The steak was very well cooked, and there was a great, smokey flavor. My mom's pork chop was also amazing--it had a deep, smokey bacon flavor from the bacon condiments on top. My lamb chop, unfortunately, was the most disappointing. It lacked flavor and it somewhat tasted like raw sashimi (which was, in my part, my own fault since I had ordered it medium rare). The quality of meat was great, but I wish there was more seasoning and a bit more time on the grill. 

We ended up each ordering a dessert, since everything on the menu looked amazing, and we got two baked Alaska, a macaroon, and a napoleon looking french pastry. My favorite was the macaroon, which had a lot of chocolate, but wasn't sweet at all. They also pour warm chocolate on the macaroon table side. The baked Alaska was a show in it of itself--the waiter poured flaming bourbon onto the cake to toast the marshmallow. The baked Alaska was light, but I wasn't a fan of the strong alcohol taste. 

I would give this place a 4.5/5, but I am rounding up because of the service and the amazing steak, pork chop, and macaroon dessert. I would recommend this place if you're staying in Vegas, and if you're looking for a more casual dining experience.

Located in Aria and it took over American Fish.
I loved the entryway and the tile circular flooring.
Inside the bar is very grand and beautiful flowers greet you. Very much like a brasserie in Paris.
We ordered the frisée salad which was good but the egg was not poached but pretty much boiled which defeats the purpose of the egg in the salad.
I ordered the heritage chicken that came with mushroom bread pudding and green beans. It tasted great except only the meat close to the bone was a little pink so I avoided eating that part. 
Also got the steak frites which was good.
The best dish was the macaroni gratinee. Never had it served this way but it was the best.
At the end they gave me some pretty flowers :)
Must go back to try the amazing looking desserts!
Unbelievable food. Perfect service.  One of the best steaks I've ever had. Better than most high steak houses on he strip and it's not even a steak house

I do not write reviews often, but tonight's meal compelled me to do so.  First off, the service here is amazing, the hostess and server were outstanding.  The appetizers we had are amazing, and the entrees exquisite.  The cocktails equally so.  I omitted my description of the food my lovely date and I had because I challenge, you the reader, to judge your dining experience for yourself!  Bon Appetite!

I have NO business going to a French restaurant.  I request everything sans beurre, sans frommage, sans lait, since my curse developed in later-life is to be unable to tolerate dairy (thank goodness it struck after an indulgent honeymoon eating through France.)  However, my dear friend wanted to enjoy a French meal, so we wondered into Bardot Brasserie.  First, I must say that the service was SUPERB, and to me, service is a make or break aspect to a meal. The waiter and wine attendant were both fun, knowledgable, informative, and just lovely.  Although the chef had every right to be un petit perturbed with a no-butter diner, he and the waiter conferred to decide what could be best modified for me, after I preemptively declined the salad nicoise.  Chacuterie plate with bread--yum!  Blue crab buckwheat crepe sans butter--good, not great-- although I did sneak a pinch of sauce on top.  Beet salad with arugula so good-fresh and nutty arugula with hazelnuts to accent the nutty flavor, went perfectly with the goat cheese (I had to have a bite of the cheese).  My friend was practically cooing with pleasure from her escargot wrapped in pastry; she said it was smooth and buttery goodness.  The suggested wine was a pleasant surprise.  I'm not a white gal (well, white wine, that is), but completely enjoyed the nectar-y German Kabinett.  Finishing sorbets--orange and mango--so fresh and clean and more fruit-filled than just icy.  Great espresso.  Overall, a wonderful, indulgent lunch and I look forward to going back soon.  SO, if this dairy-free gal can enjoy it so much, I imagine how good it is for those who are unencumbered.  5 stars for my enjoyment at Bardot Brassiere. And, I never would have known it was the 3rd day open--kudos to Bardot Brasserie!

Bardot is the place to go for an utterly decadent Vegas brunch! I think it says everything that many of us found ourselves with rosé in one hand and a Bloody Mary in the other within 15 minutes of sitting down to eat.

The Nutella cinnamon rolls were one of the best sweet breakfast items I've ever had. The brioche French toast was filthy rich and if you brunch at Bardot without ordering it you're a fool. ;) Lastly, the lobster Benedict is served atop a puff pastry and covered in a beautiful hollandaise. 

Needless to say I was overly satisfied after this indulgent meal, but it was worth the inevitable food coma. Head to the pool, get another drink, and keep going - it's Vegas!

My new favorite brunch place in Vegas. It's Michael Mina's French brasserie at the Aria. They have wonderful French breakfast like croque madame, French omelets, duck confit waffles, and steak and eggs.  Their baguettes and butter are to die for!  They also have extravagant seafood platters, great breakfast cocktails, and endless champagne pours.  It doesn't get better than this!

YUM! Going to Bardot for brunch was such a great experience! Brunch is my favorite meal of the day so I am SUPER particular, but there are so many little things here that elevated our experience... first of all the caneles were SO good. They are a French delicate pastry, and rather than order the entire basket with a bunch of various pastries, we each got one... and they were literally the best thing I ate in Vegas all weekend!! I highly recommend everyone gets one... the drinks and complimentary bread were also right on point! The food itself was good, creative takes on brunch (my eggs were in a hollowed out croissant which was good), and the ambiance was really fun! In looking back, although it would have been weird with brunch, the French onion soup that others were eating looked SO good, wish I would have ordered that instead of the hash browns, which had cheese on top that had a texture that was a little too close to melted American cheese for me (which is not something I am a big fan of...). Overall it was a really great brunch, and I would absolutely return in the future!

After Michael Mina closed out American Fish which I was fan of, I was happy to see that he opened another place in Aria. I've been here a few times for brunches and dinners since it opened. I was satisfied each time I left the restaurant. 

Service: I've received 5 star attentive services each time I was there. My bottomless rosé was always filled up before I noticed. Huge plus for me. On my recent visit, our waitress did a great job on assisting my friend picking out the menu. 

Environment: it is a casual French place. Sometimes the noise level can be quite high which I don't mind. The decor and atmosphere makes me feel like I'm actually dining in Paris. 

Food: I had more brunch experiences here than dinner. I've enjoyed my brunch items each time. Although I was disappointed that lobster Benedict is no longer on the menu. Since it's been a few years when I had the dinner here, this review is purely based on brunch. Get BOTTOMLESS rosé! For $25, it's so worth it. I also really enjoy the foie gras parfait here. It's not too salty nor it has the gaminess. The steak tartare and Escargot are also good appetizer choices to share among the table. The bread here is so yummy. My croissant Benedicts were delicious. Although I preferred the lobster one they used to have on the menu rather than short rib. I just tried their French toast yesterday. The portion was huge. The almond brittle was so yummy with the toast. I recommend to share another savory entrees or have the French toast as dessert. 

This place is definitely one of my favorite brunch spot and I highly recommend you to come check it out if you haven't already!

This place was just ok. I would give it 2.5 stars if I could but yelp doesn't do that. The menu isn't huge but does offer a pretty decent amount of options. One of my biggest complaints is the prices for what you are getting. I mean I work in fine dining and totally understand having to charge top price for quality ingredients but this place seemed to have just randomly started assigning outrageous prices all over the menu. Not to mention I felt guilt tripped by the server for not wanting to order a bottle of wine, like I'm sorry I wasn't looking for wine tonight I'm just as pleased with my beer and my bfs cocktail stop asking me if I'm sure. And the sommelier was rude, if u are going to ask how a meal was at least pretend to even listen to the response before walking away. Now onto the food cuz as I said I work in the industry and respect quality food at a high price, but even there the food was lacking. We had the oysters, good standard oysters nothing too special. Then we had the escargot which I wanted to love, but honestly wrapping them in the pastry totally took away everything and that's all you could taste, very disappointed. I had the NY Strip which was fine, once again nothing special or stand out about it and mine seemed a little too fatty, a good 1/4 of my steak was all fat which I know creates flavor but when you are getting a 12 Oz steak and at least 3oz of it is straight fat it's disappointing. My bf had the lobster which was good except the fact the bernaisse sauce overwhelmed the dish so much he couldn't even enjoy it. Plus is side of polenta with mushrooms and peas was so under seasoned we each took 1 bite and pushed it to the side to never be touched again. Overall a disappointing experience, neither of us wish to return again and defn will not be recommending this place to anyone in the future. With so many great restaurants in Las Vegas this one defn should be skipped.

You need a reservation

Delicious food! Went for brunch. Loved the bread and the steak and eggs.
Don't fall for the french toast!
Its MASSIVE and a bit under coked in areas.

I would share it if you're still determined to order it!

Very pricey though, but what in Vegas isn't lol

Bonsior

I stopped into Bardot for a cocktail and appetizer with some extremely kind friends of mine! 11.26.16.

The ambiance is amazing and the employees were extremely kind. We sat at the bar and I ordered one of the best Lobster Bisque ever! Tons of bold flavor and delicious to the last bite (trust me I consumed every last drop).

I was able to sample the CHÂTEAU DE SANCERRE
Loire Valley, France 2014 (white wine) before the bottle was purchased. Excellent choice the wine was amazing and after two glasses I felt even more amazing. 

Great place to start your evening socializing with friends!!

Great looking place with some nice reviews, however service is/was atrocious...the bartender took 20 minutes to just hand us a menu. When we ordered 2 drinks guy acted like I was asking him for a kidney. 
 eternity is much faster

second time coming here still never fails i always get a croissant benedict this time the smoked salmon perfectly flakey with the strength to hold the eggs and smoked salmon. the little cheese and fruit platter is great alongside with the fresh baguette and greatest butter from Paris . if u need a pick me up i advise to get the cappuccino perfect foam to espresso ratio. great service and great food always gotta come back here
So good. Such good food and the nicest staff! The lobster scramble was so good and they brought a cute dessert for our bachelorette celebration. Bottomless rosé brunch is

When I hear "Michael Mina" I immediately think of his Bourbon Steak in my home town Miami... I follow him for steaks not anything else, therefore I've had the fish/french dishes and they were ok. I recently gave this restaurant a 2nd try for steak and drinks and I was blown away not only by the quality of the food but the service I received from the best bartender ever Brooke. I highly recommend this place to anyone looking for a great ambiance and amazing dishes.

My bf and I were excited to try Bardot for dinner based on pictures I had seen in IG and review on here.  We were even more thrilled to find out it was by Michael Mina.  

We started with the escargots and foie gras terrine.  The escargots were prepared different from what I am used to and were beautifully presented.  IMO I think the escargot were a tad dry and chewy based on the cooking method.  The foie gras terrine was rich, creamy and just perfect.  It went very well with the crusty bread.  

For our entree, we split the bone-in rib-eye with the horseradish creme, side of mac and cheese and mushrooms.  The rib eye was cooked perfectly and had a nice crust.  I love the look of the mac and cheese which tasted like an adult updated version of the blue box from our childhood.  The mac and cheese was extremely salty for my taste which was too bad.  

Our meal was delicious and our server was very nice and sweet.  But as the meal progressed, she was non-existent.  She came back to check on us once and we never saw her again.  When my bf went to the restroom, waitstaff stopped by our table a couple of times but never picked up the empty dishes nor did they fold his napkin.  This is what I would expect.  

Overall, I might come back to Bardot.  With all the competition Las Vegas has to offer, I feel they really need to step it up in the service dept.

Had a very good, but not great, dinner at Bardot on a Friday evening.  Bardot has a large dining room, and when it is full (as it was when we dined there) it can be quite noisy.  I'm not saying this is a bad thing, it creates a good atmosphere.  But, if you are celebrating an anniversary or looking for a place to propose, I probably would look someplace else.  It'd be tough to get a romantic evening with this atmosphere.

We were seated in a large, and very comfortable, booth for our evening.  It made passing items a little tougher, but I liked it overall.  We were approached very quickly by our server and I immediately asked for the sommelier.  I really liked this guy, we told him what we were looking for, price range, and when we wanted them.  He took care of the rest, bringing wine out as we either finished a bottle or finished a course.  It was great, he only brought us fantastic stuff, and it prevented us from having to get the list out every time we needed something new.  Since none of us are knowledgeable about French wines, it was nice to tell him what we liked and have him handle it.  And, he didn't try to upsell us, he stayed within our stated budget.

As this group typically does, we shared a lot of dishes.  To start, we had the:  escargots, the royale shellfish platter, the foie gras parfait, the charcuterie board, and the hearth-fired marrow.  All were fantastic, but my favorites were the charcuterie board and marrow.  The marrow was buttery and rich, just like it should be.  It was fantastic on the toast points provided.  Were I to eat here again, I'd order two of this appetizer.  The charcuterie board had so much stuff on it we had to ask for more toast.  The pate and foie gras were excellent, which is no surprise.  The chilled shellfish was also great, save the oysters.  They were on the small side and weren't very flavorful.  The table agreed that these were the weakest part of all of the appetizers, and they are the reason Bardot doesn't get 5 stars from me.  I expected much better oysters from this place.  The escargots were served in puff pastry, which I'd not had before.  But, they had the traditional buttery rich flavor and were still winners.

For dinner, we shared:  Parisian gnocchi, croque madame, and the lamb crown roast.  The gnocchi was PHENOMENAL, probably the best gnocchi I've eaten.  It was served with wild mushrooms, goat cheese, and roasted garlic (never a bad addition to any dish).  My second favorite was probably the madame.  It was cheesy, hammy, decadence.  It's what grilled ham and cheese sandwiches want to be when they grow up.  My "least" favorite was the lamb.  And, it was still fantastic.  Juicy, cooked to a perfect medium rare, and served with a very tasty gravy on the side.  It came with a few frites, which were perfectly fried and seasoned well.  We selected some very solid entrees.  

Service was very good throughout the evening.  The place was crowded, but we never felt like we were waiting for anything.  I'd absolutely eat here again.
Best French Onion Soup Ever...Ever!  Everything on the menu is worth trying.  Steak burger was phonemonial..

Bardot is a modern French brasserie located on the 2nd floor of Aria near the convention center, in the restaurant circle. I've been here a few times and really appreciated the friendly, prompt and humble service we had here. 

The food was decent above average style Strip food, a slight edge over Mon ami Gabi (love their steak) only because of the foie gras here. 

---- Recommend ----
* Foie gras parfait - 5 stars: Smooth, decadent, and absolutely perfect with their fresh bread. 
* Hangar steak - 4 stars: Surprisingly good from what it appears but the fries were overly oily. 

---- Pass ----
* Chocolate Macaron - 3 stars: IG-worthy enormous macaron the size of your head, nothing special. 
* Mac n cheese - 2 stars: This looked so cool because it is a baked square of mac n cheese with each noodle facing up! It tasted very mediocre don't waste your stomach room on this one. 
* Steak tartare - 3 stars: Fine, standard. Liked the potato chips. Wouldn't order again
* Salad - 2 stars: Pretty terrible bland sparse salad.

The Bardot Brasserie at The Aria is a French cuisine restaurant in a tribute to the classic Parisian brasserie at its finest! The dishes here are amazing!

For starters, I had the King Crab Crepe, together with Black trumpet mushrooms, sunny-side egg, normandic cider beurre blanc. Where have you ever had a crepe prepared like this? Anywhere? Except maybe in France? All of the ingredients were blended beautifully to perfection! 

My main entree was the King Salmon Aux Lentilles, an organic Scottish salmon, beluga lentils, smoked tomato vinaigrette. Another perfect dish, indeed! The salmon was seared on the outside so the salmon skin was crunchy! After searing the outside, chef baked the salmon just enough, but leaving enough of the inside undercooked, making for another beautifully inspired dish!

For dessert, I had the Frozen Paris Brest, hazelnut ice cream, chocolate cremieux, and salted caramel. Lily, while preparing the utensils for my dessert, provided me not only with a spoon, but also a fork and knife! I jokingly asked, wow, do I really need a knife for my dessert? She laughed! When I got my dessert, yes, I'll need my knife! LOL. The dessert was actually 6 separate ice cream sandwiches craftfully connected together! It was like eating 6 ice cream sandwiches!

Props to my server Lily, who was warm and inviting through my journey through this whole experience! I will never forget her, and be sure to make a return visit here with other friends, if not on this trip, for sure in the future!

The restaurant was very elegant, high end and high class! The dishes are pricey, but hey, you get what you pay for! Right? There are flat screen TVs at the bar to make for more "casual" feel! It's a good thing we had an early dinner, 6:30, because by 7:00pm the place started to fill quickly! The whole experience here makes for my 5-star review to go with the 5-star dishes and 5-star experience! Special props to Chef Joshua Smith, under the tuitiledge of James Beard award winning chef Michael Mina! An unforgettable experience indeed! French cuisine at its finest!

Very nice expensive French restaurant at the Aria.  Even the cheapest steak ($49 flat iron) is exquisite -- they clearly make use of sous vide to get a butter texture out of the meat.  I liked the brandy-peppercorn sauce, though it wasn't the best one I've had.  I almost wish I hadn't let the waiter convince me to get that instead of the blue cheese fondue.
 
The frites that accompany the steak were good, but a little salty and a little oily.  I did like the crispness and lack of starchiness.  The lobster bisque was very good as was the bread & butter on the table.  The bread is a french sourdough and the butter is smooth, spreadable, and the right temperature.

Service was good, but not fast even after we told them some members of our party were going to a show.  

All in all a good and expensive meal.

My husband booked a reservation here because we love Steak Frites. We both had the flat iron cut- one medium well, one medium rare. My husbands steak was under cooked- rare. While we thought the meal was pretty good overall, our friends who ordered the same we're not pleased.
French toast lived up to the hype which is not easy. All other dishes were as good and the coffee from lamill was a fantastic. Service spot on too. Well done.

Very, very good.

- Very nice space.  Open and not too loud
- Service was excellent.  Attentive and knowledgeable
- The charcuterie board, especially the chicken liver pate which was rich, smooth, and had a nice bite
- The cheese board was excellent.  A nice hard goat and a semi-stinky soft cheese were both full of flavor and went very nicely with the marmalade and pears
- The lamb was perfectly cooked.  I didn't like the vegetable puree and would probably had it prepared a little differently to better bring out the lamb flavor
- The bouillabaisse was off the charts good.  Very rich and the seafood was perfectly cooked

Came here for a friend's birthday. They take reservations and was able to accommodate a party of ten. 

Atmosphere:  5 stars!  Loved the decor and look of the place. The bar was really pretty. Lots of accents of gold and marble. 

Service:  4 stars. The waiters were nice and gave us his recommendations but he forgot an order and it came out later than everyone else's. However he did give us a complimentary salmon tartine dish so that was nice. 

Food:  2 stars. Sadly... On our side of the table, none of us really liked our food. I mean it was good but it didn't blow us away. And for this price point I was really disappointed. I mean 15 dollars for soup... Had to be good right?  Nope... Didn't really enjoy it.  Between all of us we ordered basically 75% of the menu. We got all the appetizers, salads. Fish, pork chop, steak, mussels and gnocchi. Nothing was spectacular... Just ok.b I would say maybe the sea bass and the crab crepe were the best ones out of the bunch. Did not like the pate, bone marrow, froie grois, or pork chop. 

I would come here for drinks next time because it really is a cute place. Then I would go somewhere else for food.

I'd previously dined at Bardot Brasserie back in March on my last trip to Las Vegas and was unimpressed.  Not one to be deterred, the wife and I went there to see if happy hour on a Monday evening was a better experience.  While we didn't take advantage of the happy hour drink specials (I had a regular priced cocktail, a Vieux Carré instead), we did partake in the food off of the HH menu.  We shared orders of the Prime Steak Tartare and the Braised Short Rib Tartine.  I'll admit without any shame that I'm a cocktail snob.  My drink possessed all of the expected notes of the classic Vieux Carré, however, it didn't seem properly chilled.  Since it didn't taste over-diluted, I can only guess that either my drink wasn't sufficiently stirred or it was served in warm rocks glass.   Either way, it wasn't as cold and as good as it should've been.

Our food was, similarly, hit or miss.  The steak tartare was served on thin, waffle-cut, potato chips.  It was tender, meaty, and flavorful.  It was a hit with us.  The Braised Short Rib Tartine was an unfortunate miss.  The braised short rib on the tartine was rich in flavor, moist and tender.  It was made even richer with the fried egg that also came atop the tartine.  The downfall of the dish was the bread itself, which was overbaked, required sawing through it with a knife to cut it into halves for sharing, tough, and very chewy.  Don't get me wrong, it tasted fine and it wasn't worth the time and hassle of sending it back.  Still, for whatever reasons, in my experience, Bardot Brasserie continues to be the outlier in an otherwise excellent group of Michael Mina restaurants in Las Vegas.
Place is good but don't think it all dat, 3 1/2 for me. I like the escargot here, they are pretty tasty! Rather go next door for a steak!

I decided to take my girlfriend out on a nice date through Las Vegas and I decided to start the night here. It was recommended through a colleague and boy was it a great decision. Environment is right and the food is beyond sensational. Steak tartare was probably my favorite dish accompanied with some artisanal potato chips. Because it is a Brasserie, my girlfriend and I both got steaks that were cooked to perfection! 

The service went above what I expected. Friendly, patient, and took the time to talk with us and about food outside of the restaurant.

Going to make reservations very soon because I'm going back

Overall - Bardot Brasserie is a wonderful experience and I recommend dinning at this fine establishment.

 Now to the GOOD specifics:

The atmosphere here is lively and fun. It has a great vibe and much energy. Our server, Nelson, was wonderful. He was polite, knowledgeable, and seemed to really care about us. Our main dishes were fantastic. I had the Filet Mignon and my friends both had the Sole Meuniere. They were both top notch. The flavor and quality are worthy of a 5 star rating. 

Now the NOT SO GOOD specifics:

We had ordered an $88 bottle of Katheryn Kennedy Cab. from the Sommelier (sorry I don't have his name). As often happens, I expected him to counter with a similar wine up sell. He did that with a much higher end Katheryn Kennedy selling for $700! I understand sales and up selling very well, but that is a huge jump and bad business. Who knows, maybe an up sell of $20-$30 would have worked but if I'm ordering an $88 bottle of wine I can't be up sold for a bottle more than my round trip flight from New York!

As great as the main dishes were, the side dish and dessert were lacking. We shared the side dish of Blistered green beans (lemon butter & almonds). Well they were shockingly tasteless. We also ordered the chocolate macaroon for dessert and it was average at best. 

The main dishes, atmosphere and Nelson the server were so good I was thinking 5 stars here most of the evening. I had to take 1 star away for the side dish, dessert and suggestion from the Sommelier.

Hey - 4 stars is fantastic and I will be back next time I'm in Vegas. Maybe Bardot can up sell me to a 5 star rating next time :)
Really nice decor, great ambiance and atmosphere. Impeccable service. Food was also delicious. Would definitely come back here!

This has to be one of the best breakfasts I've had in a while! 

First off... the French toast is HUGE! Definitely can be split. It melts in your mouth and is accompanied with a very tasteful almond syrup concoction. This is all made even better by a light almond brittle that comes with it.

I split the above French toast and a croissant Benedict with the short rib. Adds a little more substance to your breakfast and has some fantastic flavor. 

What could make this better? Why a bottomless rose to start your Vegas day off right.

Finally, a shout out to our server Tish! The entire experience was made even better by her attention to detail and infectious personality. Thanks for the fantastic dinning experience!
Went for brunch here and it was great. Outstanding service and tried a new dish I usually do not have. Excellent iced tea and great setting that is cool and upbeat. Highly recommend!

Ate here last time we stayed in Aria, the food was excellent. I really loved the Duck and my friends loved their steak and chicken. The beef wellington was the size of a football, it could probably feed 4 ppl. The lamb chops were good but were not Frenched correctly since I kept spitting up pieces. The services is very slow, I feel like they had one waiter working the whole place. We had to beg for drinks and the food took forever to bring out. But everything was  tasty, there is room for improvement but I would come back for sure!

Had a party of 5 and made reservations for 8pm. However, we were running a bit late and needed to move our reservation back by 15 mins. The hostess was very accommodating and happily moved it back with no issue. 

By the time we arrived, we were seated very quickly and already placed our orders within 15 mins of our arrival. They also provided 2 warm, baked baguettes that were very tasty with a side of salted butter. My friends thought the bread was so good, they almpst ate all of it before our main courses. 

We ordered quite few dishes, 2 chicken plates, 1 lamb plate, 1 scallop playe, and 1 salmon plate, and 1 order of black truffle fries. We all shared a few bits and piece in order to enjoy everything we ordered. The scallops were very delicious, crispy sear on the outside and soft on the inside. The salmon plate was cooked at medium and I absolutely loved it. The chicken was very juicy and had a lot of flavor. The lamb was also delicious, it had a very light flavor in the center of the meat, but the seared portion had a wonderful taste.

Overall, the service and food was delicious. We will definitely return on our next visit to Vegas!

onion soup was great, large portion and plenty of cheese. pate was very good. chickpea frites was an interesting dish, the eggplant dip went well with the frites (chickpeas mashed and fried like French fries). steak frites was a large portion also. pork chop was a little over cooked but the horseradish whipped potatoes were amazing; lots of horseradish. wine list is expensive! cocktails are good. very large beer list. daily happy hour I missed. I would return for sure. want to try the bone marrow next time

Satisfying, fancy French dinner before seeing Zarkana.

I LOOOOOVE it when they serve cocktails on the dry side, and this place does it. I got the Notre Dame (gin, grapefruit, etc.) and it was delicious. No heaps of sugar and juice to cheapen the booze in this baby. Next time on to the more adventurous drinks with egg whites! :O

The duck l'orange was a good appetizer but also felt like eating high-class wings, which I guess is what we were doing. The French onion soup did not disappoint in taste or wads of cheese. And the mushroom gnocchi was fancy in presentation and taste.

Our waiter had an accent - whether real or not, I guess in Vegas it doesn't matter??

Oh yeah, now we're talking.

A casual modern brasserie that can challenge the best in Paris. Refinements to the menu and subtle changes to classic dishes have greatly improved the restaurant quality.  Continued innovation from the bar further heighten the experience.

Brunch, offered Saturday and Sunday, is a great way to sample the menu. The classics tartare, excellent. Hand cut prime beef mixed with coarse grain mustard and a farm fresh egg yolk.. Slathered on warm toasted baguette. Ahhhh.  Not to be outdone the escargot, tender wine braised snails surrounded by puff pastry and topped with hazelnuts and a chartreuse garlic butter. Good eats. The king crab crepe, rich goodness as the sweetness of the crab is heightened by a cider beurre blanc.  A sunny side up egg adds a velvety mouth feel and sautéed trumpet mushrooms, the classic earthiness.

The piece de resistance, and ungodly French onion soup. Beefy intensely packed full of deeply caramelized sweet onions, braised short rib, a poached egg, and black truffles, then topped by layer of melted gruyere cheese and more truffle. Mix it up and enjoy the richness of the egg as the flavors blend harmoniously together,  The portion sensibly reduced for brunch. Get this.

A good selection of cheeses, mostly imported, and a very well cooked, chilled seafood tower (king crab, lobster, oysters on the half shell, shrimp) also work with endless pours of rose ($20).

Dinner adds an excellent veal sweet bread starter. Braised turnips and trumpet mushrooms add to the enjoyment of the pillowy texture and creamy taste of the sweetbreads. Standout mains include an excellent bouillabaisse, filled with perfectly cooked sweet scallops, shrimp, mussels, clams, cod, calamari, all swimming in a saffron infuse tomato broth. Outstanding. Carnivores, do not pass on the well trimmed, simply seasoned, and perfectly cooked rack of lamb.  Meaty with just a hint of gamey funk.  

Service is very efficient and friendly.

Excellent list of craft cocktails. Many designed to pair with the food. Excellent wine list focusing mainly on France. Vegas resort pricing.

My poker bud from France sums it up perfectly.  "Meh" when learning the chef isn't French.  Translated "excellent".

Amazing French cuisine and service. 
Escargot, foie gras,bone marrow,steak tartare,duck,octopus,chicken prime rib, baked Alaska, and more. Wow. Thank you Chef Josh. And Andrea!

One of our go-to happy hours when in Vegas, upstairs restaurant area of Aria.  Glitzy looking interior, lot's of brasswork around the bar.  Feels old and new at the same time.  Good cocktails and happy hour menu at the bar.  TV's at the bar, should you be in Vegas when your favorite teams are playing.  We enjoy the small plates to share for a quick pre-dinner meal and get boozy for the start of the evening!

The restaurant is a little difficult to get to but worth the find. Beautiful interior definitely more of a dinner ambience.  Surprised that they had their own house brewed beer and great cocktails.  We enjoyed an assortment of classic french appetizers including bone marrow,  foie parfait, and a deluxe french onion soup with oxtail egg and truffle in it.  Really hit the spot before watching zarkana. Really wanna try the loup d'mer and the new Paris breast.

This place is hot for a reason, it is amazing!  Out of the many high end restaurants I have been to in Vegas this year, the only one that beats Bardot is Picasso.  I was a little worried because I found the Micheal Mina restaurant at Bellagio to be pretty disappointing.  However, it is obvious there is major passion for this venue from either Mina or the executive chef as every item in every dish was executed with care and attention to detail.  First off, duck wings "a l'orange" is absolutely a brilliant idea and were every bit as tasty as you could want.  The accompanying whipped orange sauce was divine, came in a burnt hollowed out half-orange which somehow added extra complexity to the flavor.  Amazing!  The baguette and French butter were very good, up to the quality at Bouchon.  I went with the roast chicken as it's supposed to be the signature dish here, I usually would have ordered the cod but I had to admit this dish was beautifully prepared.  The "mushroom bread pudding" will be more like thanksgiving stuffing to us Americans and was delicious when the vin juane sauce was poured over the top.  For dessert an expert apple tarte tatin, a notoriously hard dish to get right and this was the best one I've ever had.  I only wish there had been two scoops of the artisan ice cream, so creamy and tasty.  

Servers were running around like crazy and things are far from polished on that end.  Only the person who brought my wine (a great glass of Sancerre) seemed to have everything under control.  The server who brought my chicken missed the pronunciation for the sauce. This is still a pretty new place but I think they could invest more in training the staff.  Also, although the space is pretty the noise level is pretty high.

Definitely check this place out.  There were many Europeans dining there that night and I can see why.

This place is an amazing gastronomic experience! We were at the Aria for a work conference and spoiled for choice, but this ended up being our favorite as evidenced by repeat visits. When you walk in the first thing that strikes you is the floor with these tiny tiles that I swear shimmer like diamonds. If you've ever done a DIY project, you know how much work goes into laying tiny tiles and that let me know right off the bat that I was in for a fine dining experience.

The hostesses are lovely, it didn't seem to matter whether we had a reservation or was simply walking in - they were gracious both ways. Walking in the bar is immediately to your left and it's set up beautifully. The ambience is so lovely, like an upscale Parisian bistro/cafe. The customer experience is also top notch and they are very much attuned to when to serve and when to interrupt. 

Our dinner included:

French 75s: perfectly bubbly and lemony made! We asked for this drink at Alibi, Lift, Julian Serranos and none of them came close to Bardot's. Seriously, I had 4 in a row and did not pay the price in the morning. 

Classic Shrimp Cocktail: certainly passable, but nothing special - the shrimp is large and the sauce seemed standard. I would liked a bit more horseradish to kick it up. 

Charcuterie Board: this is an exquisite group appetizer with housemade pâté, pork rillettes (similar to pate), saucisson sec (thick, dry cured sausage), and bayonne ham. It was served with crostini type bread and was unbelievably flavorful!

Onion Soup Gratinee: this includes classic beef broth, baguette crostini, cave-aged gruyère. I added the beef bourguignon and black truffle, & omitted the poached egg. This soup was everything onion soup should be: flavorful broth, super cheesy topping, caramelized onions, I could go on. It was spectacular and filling!

Roasted Beets & Caramelized Goat Cheese Salad: this came with roasted red/gold beets, wild arugula, toasted hazelnuts, and tossed in a cassis vinaigrette. The beets were delicious but the goat cheese came in a round block and it wasn't that appetizing once you deconstructed the salad. It was yummy, but I would prefer for them to add the goat cheese in chunks. 

Double Cut Ribeye: oh my god, this cut of ribeye and the beef fat fries were simply unbelievable! I made the mistake of filling up on the onion soup before this and regret that decision to this day. But the half that I was able to consume was incredible. I can't remember what sauce I ordered on the side, but I didn't eat it because the steak needed no doctoring up.

Amazing food and service. In Vegas for a work conference and stumbled upon this gem while looking for a nice dinner destination.  Happened to arrive when it was time for happy hour and thoroughly enjoyed the drinks and the menu (very reasonably priced I spent less than $40 for a meal and two drinks). The Service was excellent the bartenders were extremely attentive and knowledgeable about the menu selections!

Ambiance---traditional style
Food----it's cool and not your everyday brekafast, lunch or dinner 
Service---well trained staff ; they know what they're doing

Let me start by saying I had 2 meals at the bar. The bartender who's name I don't remember was a very pretty brunette who was spot on with her service and very sociable too. The first meal I ordered 3 things. The chick pea fries which were good with lots of flavor, the tarte flambée was also very tasty but the best part of the meal was the foie gras parfait. This was maybe the best thing I have ever tasted. I spread it on my chick pea fries and my tarte . My second meal was the le steak burger. I am use to Michael Mina's burgers at Bourbon Steak in DC and this was nowhere close to those burgers. This one had good flavor but was crispy around the edges.

Another extraordinary night at Bardot, perfect execution with diverse flavors, stimulating through night end!

The Foie Gras here served two ways, both as delectable and decadent as they come. The Beluga Lentils an interesting yet fitting combination, the parfait variety a MUST have every visit!

The surprising winner here being an out of this world Creekstone Prime Rib, putting to shame anything that you've yet encountered with the prime rib label. Both flavor, texture and welcomed array of accompanying sauces putting to rest any preconceived perception of the classic dish. Order!

The Smoked Salmon Paris Brest taking same route, with an explosion of flavor and balance of taste, jading every lox and bagel forward. The caviar elevating even further and Chive Mascarpone adding a subtle sweetness and fresh bite.

And last but not least, the new Beef Wellington for Two, a generous portion, arguably enough for Four, with a fair spread of other enjoyables. Delicate beef wrapped in Prosciutto, cooked in a flaky puff pastry and stuffed with Mushroom Duxelles and soaked in Foie Gras-Madeira Veloute. Mouthwatering!

If you have not been to Bardot yet, you're missing out ;)

This place was overpriced for what it is. I had the Double Decker Croque Madame was good. It was HUGE and pretty tasty (maybe a bit too salty?) but just a little overpriced for bread, eggs, sauce and a little bit of meat. I didn't have the bloody mary but two of the girls did and said it was AMAZING (better than any they've had before).

After numerous trips to this city of broken dreams and wallets we still love to come visit. It is a wonderful weekend getaway. 
French is typically the food of choice to satisfy that craving for all things great. The bar crafted drinks were extremely tasty (although can't recall the names now they were all solid). The oysters were yum, the beef tartare well executed and the lemon merengue dessert - totally delish! 
C'est magnifique!

We ordered the Bone Marrow, Bread and Butter, Onion Soup, a 3 Cheese plate and Lamb Chop entree and Creme Brûlée for dessert. 

Our only disappointment was the Creme Brûlée. I feel a great brûlée MUST crack when whacked wit a spoon. We think they didn't torch that sugar enough. I could feel the unburnt sugar granules at the edge of the dish. 

Other than that I freakin LOVED the food. The lamb, especially, was wonderfully delicious. I will be coming back for the lamb and soup. And next time we will try the apple gratin for dessert. 

If you dig bone marrow or if you haven't tried it I simply insist you have it here! So worth it!

Such a beautiful restaurant and always the best service!! I am not a fan of fish, but was talked into trying the Sea Bass and it was amazing!! The charcuterie and cheese displays are to die for. One of Michael Mina's finest!!

Are we sure this is a Michael Mina restaurant? We had about 12 people in our party when we decided to dine at Bardot, and not a single person at the table was impressed with their meal. The decor an ambiance was very nice, but I can't say the same for our dishes. I ordered the Moules Frites which wasn't bad, but it certainly wasn't anything special. I also ordered the Second Coalition from the cocktail menu which is made up of bulldog gin, strawberry-lime cordial and sparkling wine. The drink was very sweet and honestly just tasted like strawberry syrup with sparkling wine. It definitely was not worth the price. 

I would have to say the worst part of the experience was the service. The waiter never checked on us to make sure everyone was happy with their meal, cocktail or to refresh any drinks or water. He offered to get me a different drink at the very end of the meal when I was asking for my check (insert eye roll). Needless to say, I don't think I will be returning here anytime soon.

I love salmon but HATE the skin.  Ordered it here and it was just mouth watering.  Came with skin but it was prepared nice and crunchy and I absolutely loved it.  Blew my mind.  We also shared couple of deserts.  Everything was delicious.

As French food goes this was a big meh. Went here for brunch, pretty busy and fairly expensive for the food - not great value. Nutella sticky bun was not very appetizing and very rich. Ham and cheese croque sammy was standard. French onion soup was ok, but the broth needed help. The buckwheat crepe with crab was the best part of the meal - fresh tasting and overall a pretty decent dish. Service was just ok.
Way better french food options in town elsewhere.

Amazing food, service and ambiance. I absolutely loved my experience here. My fav diah was the foie gras was paired perfectly with this delish jam and toasty bread. I can't wait to go back for round 2!

A solid 3 star rating from me. I came here two years ago and had such a wonderful experience, I had to come back here. Today's dinner was good but I wasn't  wow'd like last time. Maybe it was the service and their lobster. 

First time I was at the bar and second time (this review) was at main dining room.  Highlight of the food I've ate and highly recommend: stick with their burger and you can't go wrong. 

Lobster thermidor at $76 was over cooked. Also. why such a small lobster tail for that price? This is the reason I knocked down a star too. I think my local grocery has larger lobster tails than this! 

The foie gras appetizer was great, but why on earth did they add the lentils. Not necessary and kind of ruined the delicate piece of foie gras. 

Sea bass was a quite large dish and tasted great. A really good size portion too. 

Service at the bar was way more friendlier than the waiter we got. He was just an order taker and really didn't have any charm or personality.  Thus the other star drop, bringing this to a 3 star review. 

Maybe I had such high expectations from my first visit, but kind of left here unsatisfied.
My favorite French restaurant in Las Vegas everything is perfect there, it's pleasure to come, thank you!!!

Great service and restaurant, fairly priced! Amazing oysters and foie gras. Steak and cod also awesome. We were so stuffed that we didn't even have room for dessert, we had the cod, the oysters, foie gras, tuna Niçoise salad was also amazing. This place was all around great, just missing a bit of ambience.

I ate here for my birthday and was not disappointed. The ambience was purely fantastic. The cocktails were delicious, and he food was amazing. I had the lamb, which was moist and delicious, and my partner had the gnocchi which was a fantastic French twist- small mouthfuls of delight. Very romantic, ambient atmosphere.

After visiting Vegas several times, I finally decided to forego spending $$$ on an overpriced buffet and spend it on something worth, in my opinion, far greater value: a beautifully-prepared French meal. I started with a glass (or two?) of Brut Rosé. The group I was with ordered the Macaroni & Mimolette Gratinée to try out. Loved the presentation of it! I went with the Rack of Lamb and Frites for my entree. The lamb was absolutely tender and just so delicious!  It was cooked to perfection (i.e. medium rare), and the basil and garlic sauce was a nice compliment to the lamb without being overpowering. The chickpea fries were a pleasant surprise and something I would love to have again! If you're looking for a meal worth spending money on, I highly recommend visiting Bardot!
Amazing food. Me and my wife went last night and we're very impressed. Service was great

Brunch...

Hunter's Waffle.
Croissant Benedict w/ Maine Lobster.
French Toast.

Hecka good! Especially that French Toast!
#smackin

I love Bardotttt! this is the place I celebrate my birthday. High expectation and they earned my respect. The service is perfect. Gave me enough information about the food and suggestion on the wine is hit my point. The Rib-eye is really tender and juicy with fatty fries and sauce. (One of the best rib-eye I ever had) I didn't finish because the rib-eye is big for me. I also ordered the dessert. Everything is perfect and I will definitely come back. Price is a little high but worth it.

Came here with three of my girlfriends and shared one entree, one side, and one appetizer. We weren't that hungry and didn't want to be too stuffed before going out. The amount we ordered ended up being perfect (bc we also had the bread they brought for the table). Can't miss out on the "best butter in the world." Honestly the butter was good! But it was pretty average compared to butter at any other nice restaurant. Really delicious rib eye and black truffle fries!! the sauces on the side perfectly complimented the meat. It is pretty heavy though. The fries were more airy than expected but very crispy and hot. The Brussels sprouts were not the best I've ever had but still tasty? They were a little too flavored with vinegar. The charcuterie board was good! The little pickles were to die for!!! The prosciutto and salami were tasty. overall this restaurant is very cute and has a nice ambience. It isn't it of this works but would definitely come back!

Came here for Happy Hour and found two amazing things:
-The chicken sandwich dip
-Eric, the bartender

Besides serving up a nice strong sidecar, Eric really made me want to return to this place, thanks to his friendly nature and great conversation.  Guys like him are the reason people like to spend time in bars (besides the alcohol).  Not only did he make us feel right at home, by treating us as if we were lifelong pals, he also asked us about our dinner plans and pointed us in the direction of Carbone, which was right across the way and did not disappoint.

Thanks Eric and thanks Bardot!

Had such a lovely experience dining at Bardot.  The service was great.  Fun atmosphere but a little loud in the main dining area.  The food was excellent!  Our server personally offered items that he tried himself and they were great choices.  I look forward to coming back here on any future trips to LV.

3.5 stars.  You know, everything was really tasty, from the fresh warm mini-baguettes fresh out of the oven to the steak frites.  But, there was heavy-handedness in the salting of the entrees, so much so, that I woke up feeling hung over and completely bloated.  It was a great experience while we were there, but I won't return because of the over-salting issue.  Steaks delicious, though one of my dining partners ordered medium-well and got medium to medium rare.  Can't understand how that type of establishment can goof up on the cook.  I would have given 4.5 stars, if not for the excess salt issue.

I was underwhelmed. 

The overall ambiance was nice. Clean and classic without being overly fancy. That being said, I felt that the food was priced higher than it should have been. I understand it cost more to eat better quality, but this just didn't meet the standard I was expecting for the price point. The service was ok, but it took a really long time for our order to come out. 30 - 45 min. Bubs ordered the crab crepe ($22). He liked it but I was not a fan at all. I ordered the beet salad. Flavors were on point with what I expected, but there really wasn't much food. When I order a salad I imagine a plate with lettuce and fixings. This was a cut up beet with a goat cheese wheel and some arrugala laid on top. Not really worth $19. The best part were the truffle fries. Cooked and seasoned to perfection, they were the saving grace of the meal. My friends ordered the pork chop and the lobster bisque. Both said their food was ok. For the damage it put on my credit card, I was expecting more.

Came here for a Bachlorette party and waited at least 20 minutes for our table even tho we had a reservation at 9pm. The hostess and the waiter both apologised and we hung out at the bar so it wasn't too bad. 

In terms of food, it was decent but again nothing memorable. We picked this place cuz we stayed at the Aria and they can accommodate a big group. 
The complimentary French bread that came with the meal was great and we ordered their "world best butter" for $8 a pop. The butter was very silly and creamy but we didn't think it lived up to its name. We thought the complimentary butter was just as good. 

Overall, food was decent but again, Vegas has a lot
Of great restaurants to offer so I probably won't come back anytime soon.

This place was AMAZING!!! Came here with the sister-in-law, brother-in-law, and the hubby while we were in Vegas for a little vaca. We had 11:45am reservations on Sunday for brunch! We were seated right away.

We ordered the Paris ham croissant benedict ($16), the french toast ($16), the hunter's waffle ($19) and a nutella sticky bun for the table ($16). While we waited, they brought a couple of small baguettes for the table and some yummy salted whipped butter. 

The food was all amazing. The french toast was HUGE!!! Waaaaay too much for one person and a little too rich. I felt like I would have had a sugar coma after consuming it. The hunter's waffle looked good. My brother-in-law seemed to be enjoying it. The croissant benedict was as delicious as it sounded. What better to have as the base for an eggs benedict than a flakey buttery croissant? It was soooooo good! 

The clear winner for the brunch was the nutella sticky bun. It was melt in your mouth, sticky, gooey, goodness. I'm glad we got one to split for the table though, because just having that for breakfast is pretty dangerous. 

This place was so good we wanted an encore performance the next day, but sadly, they do not serve brunch on weekdays =( 
It's a little pricey, but well worth the splurge!

If there is one 'problem' with friends and family visits it is mostly deciding which Restaurants to dine at, the balancing act of personal favorites and places that will please a variety of palates not all that tough here in Sin City but trimming a "best of the best" list becoming more difficult as everyone continues to raise the bar, though few have gone so far as to reinvent a genre like Josh Smith at Bardot Brasserie.

Now sailing smoothly in year three, a similar space from Celebrity Chef Michael Mina called Margeaux since opened in Chicago, it was alongside five others including four first-timers that seats were taken at a rounded table on Saturday night, familiar servers bustling around a jammed-packed room with music chiming overhead and the scene not dissimilar to what one will find in Paris or Lyon at 9:00pm, but here shifted a few hours earlier.

Recently transitioning from Winter to Spring, a "seasonal" change from Chef Smith and his team not merely a shift in set-ups but entailing the invention of several new plates, it was with an opening glass of Champagne that friends new and old exchanged cheers before slathering world-class Butter on Baguettes now served by the basket, a sweet n' salty Endive and Blue Cheese Salad the first new dish of the evening presented alongside ground-to-order Tartare and silky smooth Mousse that even those who claim not to like Liver found irresistible.

Never lacking for quality ingredients or creativity, a second plate of Foie Gras served seared atop Wild Rice with diced Root Vegetables providing a foil to Cabbage Agre-Doux, those looking for a highlight from the new menu would do well to order a plate of charred Octopus served spicy with White Beans while Bardot's Bone Marrow remains another good choice, though the presentation is not quite as eye-widening as Jean Georges Steakhouse next door. 

Moving at a comfortable pace with serviceware replaced and glasses refilled frequently it was with Laguiole Knives in hand that entrees were served in two rounds as the table soon filled, Chef Smith's Beef Wellington once again outperforming any other seen to-date by anyone present while Duck recently added to the menu showed similar to the Foie Gras, a sizable Breast with crisp skin resting earthy ingredients brightened up by the addition of Huckleberries adding just a touch of natural Sugar.

Getting even more Spring-like with Lamb and Scallops, two cases where a change in set-up improved nicely-prepared proteins with a plethora of seasonal Produce that all contributed something novel yet complimentary, it was at the request of Josh that guests next weighed in on a concept dish, the fact that there is no literature on Buckwheat Pate a Choux not as issue for the locally born Chef as each Dumpling was indistinguishable from standard Flour save for a light nuttiness that contributed to the forest-floor  medly of Morels, Cepes, Black Truffles and Asparagus.

Pumping the brakes for Cheese, a good selection highlighted by the same Tete de Moine served atop Gnocchi plus runny Perail de Brebis and housemade Condiments on thick slate, it was with Espresso cleansing the palate that every single one of Bardot's Desserts arrived in a truly Grand Finale, a special request also seeing a block of fluffy Brioche French Toast held over from Brunch and the only "disappointment" being that some were already too full to enjoy as much as they'd have liked to while one in particular had given up Chocolate for Lent.

***** Say what you will about Michael Mina, Celebrity Chefs, high-volume Restaurants or Las Vegas in general, the simple fact is that when looking world-wide at "Brasseries" from North America to France there are none outperforming Bardot day-in/day-out or plate-for-plate and if Chef Smith were in New York or Los Angeles he'd be getting James Beard nominations while spots like Le Coucou would be forced to step up their game rather than resting on their laurels.

Food was pretty good. We got the oyster sampler. The west coast oysters were better than the east coast oysters. The main courses were good but portions do run a little small. Average price for a main course was about $35.

Came here for Sunday brunch and this place is overrated. We wanted to impress my friend who traveled in from Singapore but our server was just rude and very aloof. Maybe because we didn't order any drinks or appetizers. Honestly, I was all for ordering apps but upon finding out that in all of Aria Resort , BARDOT cannot manage to find any gluten free bread or crackers for the growing population of gluten intolerant guests. I was stuck ordering a $30 salad that was just a bunch of lettuce leaves and a boiled chicken. My friends had the duck confit, the French toast and American breakfast and they were not impressed for the price that we paid! I don't know how this place got mentioned on the 2018 Eater list of must do brunches in Vegas! Don't waste your time or your money!
Claims to be an european/french restaurant. I ordered a Latte Machiatto and they didnt have a clue of what that was. Got a Latte instead. Food was mediocre as well. Bread and pastries are delicious.

I believe I had better French food in the ghettos of Paris next to the guy pissing with near subway station. Michael Mina should be a shamed of the overpriced menu grilled macaroni that my seven-year-old can make better.


Avoid like a bad virus on French bread.

Great spot for brunch! We rolled in 16 people deep.Great food, great service!

Talk about indulgence:

SEASONAL FRUIT - frozen yogurt-pistachio parfait, buckwheat beignets. When in Vegas, you can't go wrong with fruit and beignets.
PRIME STEAK TARTARE -ground to order, sauce verte, egg yolk, toasted baguette. Couldn't get enough.
Maine Lobster Croissant Benedict - Love the croissant twist - eggs were perfectly poached, and filled with ample amounts of lobster! 

For Dessert!
MILLE FEUILLE - caramelized puff pastry, vanilla crème pâtissière
CRÈME BRÛLÉE - vanilla bean custard, turbinado croquant

And bottomless sparkling rose for $25 or rose for $20?! Must keep the good feeling going..

Amazing French food for a reasonable price. Highlights include:
King crab crepe - super fresh crab with a buckwheat crepe and hollandaise sauce = superb
Lobster egg Benedict - tasty lobster, very gracious with the amount of lobster, over a flaky croissant.. What's not to like?
Seafood tower - a must have if you're with a large party. Oysters are delicious, king crab legs are super meaty and the shrimp is amazing!
Quiche - probably the highlight of the meal, I don't normally like quiche but this was a very flavorful and flaky quiche that just melts in your mouth

Service was fantastic and attentive, I'd recommend going here hands down!

I went in with a group (Lip Smacking Foodie Tours) and was blown away.  The staff was friendly and professional and the food (deconstructed Niçoise salad and the duck wings are a MUST) was delicious.  I'm bringing my GF with me next time, a perfect "date night" spot.....

Cheers!

King crab crepe! Omg. Flavor combination out of this world. Buckwheat crepe, don't let that scare you, trumpet mushrooms and sunny side up egg. Decadence!!! Hunters waffle also out of this world. Belgium waffle, duck, poached egg.  You should also try the short rib Benedict. All great choices and $20 all you can drink...rose...sparkling or dry. Heavenly brunch!

When we want brunch on the strip at a decent price with impeccable service, we do BARDOT! Eric the bartender is one of the most genuine severs in the business. The French twist and ambiance is charming, and the place is peppered with fresh pink roses, a favorite of mine! Rose all day for a flat fee is a perk too. In the mood for a burger, they've got you covered. Want homemade quiche? Look no further. The salmon platter has the cutest loaf of bread and the accompaniments are on point. We've had the French toast to start as you could share with an army. Don't forget to try the syrup!  See you soon, Eric!

Wow, this place has great food and service.  The wait staff are knowledgeable and super friendly.  The food is outstanding, one of the best espressos I found in Las Vegas.  Try the chocolate macaroons it is fantastic.

I have only had phenomenal experiences here at BARDOT, both as an individual and when booking for a whole group.

The Sidecar is 100% my favorite cocktail and their sidecar is on point! I stayed at the Aria for a conference and am so grateful that Bardot was here!

If you come during happy hour the price of the drinks plus the complementary baguette and butter (which is delicious) make it all worth it.

For dinner I had the pork chop and it was well worth it! Glistening white, perfectly cooked and plenty flavorful, I was very impressed by my meal. 5 stars!

We went to Bardot Brasserie thinking that we would find a replica of a Paris brasserie. Well, the décor is very well designed, the service by Shannon very friendly and that's where the similarity ends. My wife's omelette seemed to come out of a pan of pre-made rolls, my lobster tasted somewhat blend, no home made sauce to accompany the dishes. So we were disappointed by the lack of culinary research and the wine glasses at $18 seem to be somewhat overpriced. Oh but we were in Las Vegas where everything is "oversized"!. chef Mina, you have a little way to go to reach the quality we were expecting for that price range.

We were very pleased with this brasserie menu and execution made feel very authentic. It's a great lunch or heavy snack option. The escargot en croute was an especially nice surprise, great la beouf hache, and pate.

Visited this lovely restaurant over the weekend for brunch and it was seriously perfection. Loved the complimentary assorted bread basket and baguette...my group of 4 ended up sharing the entire bread basket and we are not sorry we did. The quality of the Onion Soup broth was incredible and just the right amount of cheese on top. I had the Chicken French Dip as my main dish and that too did not disappoint. I can't wait to visit Vegas again just so I can dine here for lunch/dinner!

Boy, restaurants in Las Vegas have sure come a long way  :). The BARDOT is located in the Aria hotel. This is very much a high end restaurant. The service is impeccable and the ambience is tasteful. 

I went here for dinner with a colleague and we both enjoyed this restaurant very much. For drinks, I started with the Moscow Mule. It wasn't on the cocktail menu but the server assured me that they made it very well, and he was right. It was excellent. We then had a cab. for dinner, which was very good as well.
